AMS 10 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.description: Applications-oriented course on complex numbers and linear algebra integrating Matlab as a computational support tool. Introduction to complex algebra. Vectors, bases and transformations, matrix algebra, solutions of linear systems, inverses and determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and geometric transformations. Students cannot receive credit for this course and for courses 10A or Mathematics 21.
AMS 10 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): score of 400 or higher on the  mathematics placement examination (MPE)  or Mathematics 3.
AMS 10 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.title: AMS 10 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Engineers I

AMS 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.description: Introduction to mathematical tools and reasoning, with applications to economics. Topics are drawn from differential calculus in one variable and include limits, continuity, differentiation, elasticity, Taylor polynomials, and optimization. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and Mathematics 11A or 19A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15A. (Also offered as Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A. Students cannot receive credit for both courses.)
AMS 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.enrollment_requirements: Students who have already taken Mathematics 11A or 19A should not take this course. Prerequisite(s): score of 300 or higher on the mathematics placement examination (MPE), Applied Math and Statistics 2, 3, or 6, or Mathematics 3.
AMS 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.title: AMS 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for Economists I

AMS 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.description: Mathematical tools and reasoning, with applications to economics. Topics are drawn from multivariable differential calculus and single variable integral calculus, and include partial derivatives, linear and quadratic approximation, optimization with and without constraints, Lagrange multipliers, definite and indefinite integrals, and elementary differential equations. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and Mathematics 11B or 19B or Applied Math and Statistics 15B.
AMS 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11A , Economics 11A, Mathematics 11A, or Mathematics 19A.
AMS 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for Ec.title: AMS 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for Economists II

AMS 131 - 01 Introduction to Probability.description: Introduction to probability theory and its applications. Combinatorial analysis, axioms of probability and independence, random variables (discrete and continuous), joint probability distributions, properties of expectation, Central Limit Theorem, Law of Large Numbers, Markov chains. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 203 and Computer Engineering 107.
AMS 131 - 01 Introduction to Probability.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11B or Economics 11B or Mathematics 11B or 19B or 20B.
AMS 131 - 01 Introduction to Probability.title: AMS 131 - 01 Introduction to Probability Theory

AMS 20 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.description: Applications-oriented class on ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and systems of ODEs using Matlab as a computational support tool. Covers linear ODEs and systems of linear ODEs; nonlinear ODEs using substitution and Laplace transforms; phase-plane analysis; introduction to numerical methods. Students cannot receive credit for this course and for courses 20A or Mathematics 24. (Formerly AMS 20.)
AMS 20 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 19B, and course 10 or 10A or Mathematics 21.
AMS 20 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Eng.title: AMS 20 - 01 Mathematical Methods for Engineers II

AMS 5 - 01 Statistics.description: Introduction to statistical methods/reasoning, including descriptive methods, data-gathering (experimental design and sample surveys), probability, interval estimation, significance tests, one- and two-sample problems, categorical data analysis, correlation and regression. Emphasis on applications to the natural and social sciences. Students cannot receive credit for this course if they have already received credit for course 7.
AMS 5 - 01 Statistics.title: AMS 5 - 01 Statistics

AMS 5 - 02 Statistics.description: Introduction to statistical methods/reasoning, including descriptive methods, data-gathering (experimental design and sample surveys), probability, interval estimation, significance tests, one- and two-sample problems, categorical data analysis, correlation and regression. Emphasis on applications to the natural and social sciences. Students cannot receive credit for this course if they have already received credit for course 7.
AMS 5 - 02 Statistics.title: AMS 5 - 02 Statistics

AMS 7 - 01 Statistical Methods for the B.description: Case-study-based introduction to statistical methods as practiced in the biological,  environmental, and health sciences. Descriptive methods, experimental design, probability, interval estimation, hypothesis testing, one- and two-sample problems, power and sample size calculations, simple correlation and simple linear regression, one-way analysis of variance, categorical data analysis.
AMS 7 - 01 Statistical Methods for the B.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): score of 300 or higher on the mathematics placement examination (MPE), or course 2 or 3 or 6 or 11A or 15A or Mathematics 3 or 11A or 19A. Concurrent enrollment in course 7L is required.
AMS 7 - 01 Statistical Methods for the B.title: AMS 7 - 01 Statistical Methods for the Biological, Environmental, and Health Sciences

AMS 80A - 01 Gambling and Gaming.description: Games of chance and strategy motivated early developments in probability, statistics, and decision theory. Course uses popular games to introduce students to these concepts, which underpin recent scientific developments in economics, genetics, ecology, and physics.
AMS 80A - 01 Gambling and Gaming.title: AMS 80A - 01 Gambling and Gaming

ANTH 100 - 01 History and Theory of Biol.description: Provides an historical overview from the 18th century to the present of race, ape-human relationships, and human nature. Emergence of an evolutionary framework and of fossil, genetic, and primate information becomes the basis for reformulating ideas about human biology within anthropology.
ANTH 100 - 01 History and Theory of Biol.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 1, 2, and 3 and satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
ANTH 100 - 01 History and Theory of Biol.title: ANTH 100 - 01 History and Theory of Biological Anthropology

ANTH 107B - 01 Methods and Research in B.description: This combination of lectures, readings, discussions, and hands-on laboratory experience provides a comprehensive overview of stable isotope research to reconstruct diet and mobility. Discover the wide application of isotopic research in biological anthropology, bioarcheology, primatology and forensics. Prerequisite(s): at least one of ANTH 101, ANTH 104, ANTH 106, ANTH 107, or ANTH 110F and by permission of the instructor. (Formerly Methods and Research in Stable Isotope Ecology.)
ANTH 107B - 01 Methods and Research in B.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 101 or 104 or 106 or 107 or 110F.
ANTH 107B - 01 Methods and Research in B.title: ANTH 107B - 01 Methods and Research in Biological Anthropology: Stable Isotopes

ANTH 110P - 01 India and Indian Diaspora.description: Explores several themes of relevance in contemporary India and Indian diaspora, concentrating on anthropological research and various documentary and popular Bollywood films. Through films and ethnographies, students analyze the nature of anthropological contributions to the study of Indian societies. (Formerly course 80P.)
ANTH 110P - 01 India and Indian Diaspora.title: ANTH 110P - 01 India and Indian Diaspora through Film

ANTH 110S - 01 Evolution of Democracy.description: Examines the state and its institutions from a historical, social, and cross-cultural perspective, paying attention to the varied discourses and practices that constitute what we call "the state."
ANTH 110S - 01 Evolution of Democracy.title: ANTH 110S - 01 Evolution of Democracy

ANTH 110V - 01 Virtual Values: The Cultu.description: Examines social, political, and cultural implications of technology, with an emphasis on information technology and its relationship to capitalism in the U.S. Draws on theories of capitalism and technology, commodities and affective labor, ethnographies of technological workplaces, and other histories.
ANTH 110V - 01 Virtual Values: The Cultu.title: ANTH 110V - 01 Virtual Values: The Cultural Politics of Information Technology

ANTH 110Y - 01 Feeding California.description: Online course introducing students to social practices, political processes, and cultural contexts that shape food production and consumption. Considers identity, heritage, choice, power, agency, body practices, belonging, access, safety, and security. Prioritizes California case studies, with comparative examples from around the world.
ANTH 110Y - 01 Feeding California.title: ANTH 110Y - 01 Feeding California

ANTH 130F - 01 Blackness In Motion: Anth.description: What connects "Black" communities in the Caribbean, the U.S., Latin America, and Canada, and what sets them apart? This course examines theories of diaspora, gender and sexuality, slavery, colorism, music, U.S. hegemonies, social movements, and comparative racialization and global anti-blackness(Formerly African Diasporas in the Americas.)
ANTH 130F - 01 Blackness In Motion: Anth.title: ANTH 130F - 01 Blackness In Motion: Anthropology of the African Diaspora

ANTH 147 - 01 Anthropology and the Anthr.description: Looks at how humans have lived with their environments in other times and places; the long-distance transfers of humans and other animals, as well as plants and microorganisms; and how we can best live in the Anthropocene.
ANTH 147 - 01 Anthropology and the Anthr.title: ANTH 147 - 01 Anthropology and the Anthropocene

ANTH 188C - 01 Practicum in Archaeology.description: Two-credit course introducing practical skills in archaeological materials identification of stone, shell, bone, and other materials; curation; and database management. Students receive entry-level training with once-weekly class meetings and five hours per week of hands-on work. Prerequisite(s): ANTH 1, ANTH, 2, and ANTH 3. Part three of a three-course series, which also includes ANTH 188A and ANTH 188B, required for the archaeology major. May be repeated for credit.
ANTH 188C - 01 Practicum in Archaeology.title: ANTH 188C - 01 Practicum in Archaeology C

ANTH 3 - 01 Introduction to Archaeology.description: Overview of ways of learning about the human past beyond the scope of written history. Reviews development of archaeology, fundamental methods and theories, and archaeology's contribution to understanding human origins, the emergence of farming, and the origins of complex societies.
ANTH 3 - 01 Introduction to Archaeology.title: ANTH 3 - 01 Introduction to Archaeology

APLX 113 - 01 Inter-Cultural Communicati.description: Examines intercultural communication and miscommunication between individuals and speech communities, both within North American and global contexts. Through discourse and analytic approaches, students explore cultural stereotypes and interactional expectations, among other issues, that influence the outcome of intercultural communication. (Formerly Languages 113, Cross-Cultural Communication and Miscommunication.)
APLX 113 - 01 Inter-Cultural Communicati.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to juniors and seniors.
APLX 113 - 01 Inter-Cultural Communicati.title: APLX 113 - 01 Inter-Cultural Communication

APLX 80 - 01 Introduction to Applied Lin.description: Introduces the field of applied linguistics, learning about language acquisition, use, and teaching in multilingual contexts from multiple disciplinary perspectives. Also, introduces research models that examine psycholinguistic, sociolinguistic, and/or educational aspects of multilingualism..
APLX 80 - 01 Introduction to Applied Lin.title: APLX 80 - 01 Introduction to Applied Linguistics

ART 101 - 01 Introduction to Computer Pr.description: Combines an introduction to computer programming for beginners with special topics that are essential for the digital arts. Basic concepts of programming are developed in the JavaScript language and applied to digital arts media, such as algorithmically generated still images and animations in two and three dimensions, sound art, and music composition. Presentation of digital artwork in the theater and via the web are covered in detail.
ART 101 - 01 Introduction to Computer Pr.title: ART 101 - 01 Introduction to Computer Programming for the Arts

ART 10F - 01 4D Foundation.description: Introduces students to the fundamental principles of four-dimensional/time-based art and design through basic concepts, techniques, and technical practices. Computers and video, photo, sound, and lighting equipment are used to create short-form, time-based work. This course is a hybrid studio/lecture.
ART 10F - 01 4D Foundation.title: ART 10F - 01 4D Foundation

ART 20G - 01 Introduction to Print Media.description: Introduces the methods, materials, and history of printmaking and drawing as a tool for creative exploration. Understanding and development of concepts and skills are achieved through a series of lectures, studio demonstrations and practice, assignments, and critiques. Students are billed for a materials fee.
ART 20G - 01 Introduction to Print Media.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): two courses from 10D, 10E, or 10F. Enrollment is restricted to proposed art and art majors.
ART 20G - 01 Introduction to Print Media.title: ART 20G - 01 Introduction to Print Media and Drawing

ART 20H - 01 Introduction to Sculpture a.description: Introduces sculpture and art in public space. The course is composed of lectures, readings, discussions, studio assignments, and demonstrations. Students are billed for a materials fee.
ART 20H - 01 Introduction to Sculpture a.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): two courses from Art 10D, 10E, or 10F. Enrollment is restricted to proposed art and art majors.
ART 20H - 01 Introduction to Sculpture a.title: ART 20H - 01 Introduction to Sculpture and Public Art

ART 20J - 01 Introduction to Drawing and.description: Introduces the material practices of painting in combination with the formal vocabulary of the visual arts. A discussion of values, form, color, and figure/ground relationships enters into each class. Students are billed for a materials fee.
ART 20J - 01 Introduction to Drawing and.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): two courses from Art 10D, 10E, or 10F. Enrollment is restricted to proposed art and art majors.
ART 20J - 01 Introduction to Drawing and.title: ART 20J - 01 Introduction to Drawing and Painting

ART 80D - 01 Introduction to Photography.description: Introductory course for beginners. Various techniques examined and assigned in specific exercises. Work on projects using color film; this is a non-darkroom course. Examples given of photography from 1826 to the present. Balances historical study and practice through assigned homework exercises. Students must provide their own camera, preferably one with a manual setting. No phone cameras allowed. Students are billed a materials fee.
ART 80D - 01 Introduction to Photography.title: ART 80D - 01 Introduction to Photography

ART 80E - 01 Environmental Art in the Ex.description: Examines the ways artists engage, interact, and comment upon ecology and nature in their artworks by examining environmental art from the 1960s through the present. Offers students a foundational introduction to art and artists working in the field of environmental and ecological art/activism.
ART 80E - 01 Environmental Art in the Ex.title: ART 80E - 01 Environmental Art in the Expanded Field

ARTG 120 - 01 Game Design Experience.description: Teaches the concrete skills associated with making a digital game, from start to finish. Activities include establishing a team, concepting, storyboarding, prototyping, producing, and testing a game for release. Students are organized into groups and work together to create and produce a playable game. Students are billed a materials fee.
ARTG 120 - 01 Game Design Experience.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 80H or 80I; and  Computer Science 12B and 12M and Computational Media 80K and Film and Digital Media 80V. Concurrent enrollment in Computational Media 120 is required.
ARTG 120 - 01 Game Design Experience.title: ARTG 120 - 01 Game Design Experience

ARTG 80I - 01 Foundations of Play.description: Understanding the foundations of play through reading influential texts; in-class lectures and activities; designing and "playtesting" games; and the ethnographies of players in the physical world. Students are billed a materials fee. (Formerly Art 80I.)
ARTG 80I - 01 Foundations of Play.title: ARTG 80I - 01 Foundations of Play

ASTR 2 - 01 Overview of the Universe.description: An overview of the main ideas in our current view of the universe, and how they originated. Galaxies, quasars, stars, pulsars, and planets. Intended primarily for nonscience majors interested in a one-quarter survey of classical and modern astronomy.
ASTR 2 - 01 Overview of the Universe.title: ASTR 2 - 01 Overview of the Universe

ASTR 3 - 01 Introductory Astronomy: Plan.description: Properties of the solar system and other planetary systems. Topics include the Sun, solar system exploration, the physical nature of the Earth and the other planets, comets and asteroids, the origin of the solar system, the possibility of life on other worlds, planet formation, and the discovery and characterization of planets beyond the solar system. Intended for nonscience majors. Courses 3, 4, and 5 are independent and may be taken separately or sequentially. (Formerly Introductory Astronomy: The Solar System.)
ASTR 3 - 01 Introductory Astronomy: Plan.title: ASTR 3 - 01 Introductory Astronomy: Planetary Systems

ASTR 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in.description: Introduction to research for first-year students interested in physics and astrophysics. Students complete projects in small groups with scientists. Introduces techniques for collaboration; science writing; physics careers. Continuing course spanning two quarters. Prerequisite(s): course 9A. Enrollment is restricted to first-year proposed applied physics, physics, and physics (astrophysics) majors and by permission of the instructor.
ASTR 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in.title: ASTR 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in Physics and Astrophysics

ASTR 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in.description: Introduction to research for first-year students interested in physics and astrophysics. Students complete projects in small groups with scientists. Introduces techniques for collaboration; science writing; physics careers. Continuing course spanning two quarters. Prerequisite(s): course 9A. Enrollment is restricted to first-year proposed applied physics, physics, and physics (astrophysics) majors and by permission of the instructor.
ASTR 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in.title: ASTR 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in Physics and Astrophysics

BIOE 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.description: A survey of the diversity, structure, and functioning of California's ecosystems through time and the ways they have influenced and responded to human activities and stewardship. Topics include: ecosystem drivers such as climate, soils, and land-use history; human and ecological prehistory; comparative marine, freshwater, and terrestrial ecosystem dynamics; and managed ecosystems such as range, fisheries, and agriculture.
BIOE 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 20C. Enrollment is restricted to ecology and evolution, marine biology, plant sciences, and biology B.A. majors.
BIOE 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.title: BIOE 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California

BIOL 126 - 01 Advanced Molecular Neurosc.description: Explores in detail cellular and molecular events that underlay the function of the nervous system. Topics include neural development, axon guidance and regeneration, advanced electrical principles (synaptic transmission through a variety of receptors), synaptic plasticity, learning and memory, as well as several neural disorders. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 226.
BIOL 126 - 01 Advanced Molecular Neurosc.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 125. Enrollment is restricted to neuroscience majors and proposed majors.
BIOL 126 - 01 Advanced Molecular Neurosc.title: BIOL 126 - 01 Advanced Molecular Neuroscience

BIOL 188 - 01 A Life in Medicine.description: Students explore healthcare from the perspectives of both clinicians and patients. The class focuses on medicine's cognitive, emotional, and spiritual elements, with the goal of understanding the rewards and costs of healthcare practice. (Formerly Life in Healthcare.)
BIOL 188 - 01 A Life in Medicine.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to junior and senior human biology majors, and others by permission of instructor.
BIOL 188 - 01 A Life in Medicine.title: BIOL 188 - 01 A Life in Medicine

BIOL 80A - 01 Female Physiology and Gyne.description: Biochemical, medical, social, and clinical aspects of the female body. Emphasis will be on biological-chemical interactions in the female organs. Topics include female anatomy, cell physiology, endocrine functions, sexuality and intimacy, sexually transmitted diseases, puberty, pregnancy, menopause, birth control, abortion, immunity, cancer.
BIOL 80A - 01 Female Physiology and Gyne.title: BIOL 80A - 01 Female Physiology and Gynecology

BIOL 88 - 01 Studies in Medicine: Its Ar.description: An interdisciplinary, multicultural, and historical perspective of medicine focused primarily upon therapy and practice to achieve better understanding of the scope, practice, and limits or medicine.
BIOL 88 - 01 Studies in Medicine: Its Ar.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
BIOL 88 - 01 Studies in Medicine: Its Ar.title: BIOL 88 - 01 Studies in Medicine: Its Art, History, Science, and Philosophy

BME 129C - 01 Project Design and Impleme.description: Final part of a three-course sequence that is the culmination of the bioengineering program for students who chose a senior design group project to fulfill their capstone requirement. Students apply knowledge and skills gained in biomolecular engineering coursework to articulate, organize, and plan a senior design group project. Student groups complete research, specification, planning, and procurement for their project. Includes technical discussions, design reviews, and formal presentations. Students are billed a materials fee.
BME 129C - 01 Project Design and Impleme.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 129A and 129B. Enrollment is restricted to senior bioengineering majors.
BME 129C - 01 Project Design and Impleme.title: BME 129C - 01 Project Design and Implementation in Biomolecular Engineering III

BME 160 - 01 Research Programming in the.description: No programming experience is required, but basic computer and molecular biology understanding is assumed. Students learn programming in Python to manipulate biological data. Programming assignments comprise the majority of the assignments, and a final project using skills developed in this course is required. Lab section registration is required. BioPython and other modules introduced for use in the final project.
BME 160 - 01 Research Programming in the.title: BME 160 - 01 Research Programming in the Life Sciences

BME 163 - 01 Applied Visualization and A.description: Python and its Numpy, Scipy, and Matplotlib packages as well as Inkscape are used on scientific data to generate "publication-quality" figures. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 263.
BME 163 - 01 Applied Visualization and A.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 160 or course 205. Prerequisites can be waived in cases where students have the required programming skills. Enrollment is restricted to juniors and seniors.
BME 163 - 01 Applied Visualization and A.title: BME 163 - 01 Applied Visualization and Analysis of Scientific Data

BME 177 - 01 Engineering Stem Cells.description: For bioengineering students interested in stem cells. Class uses project-based learning to discuss basic stem cell concepts and past breakthrough approaches to identify and design solutions for technological hurdles in stem cell research.
BME 177 - 01 Engineering Stem Cells.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 140 or 150, and BIOL 100, or by consent of instructor.
BME 177 - 01 Engineering Stem Cells.title: BME 177 - 01 Engineering Stem Cells

BME 180 - 01 Professional Practice in Bi.description: Seminar course where students develop a research proposal and the collaborative skills needed for independent research projects. Includes professional practice development in collaboration skills, project management, proposal development, and funding.
BME 180 - 01 Professional Practice in Bi.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): previous or concurrent enrollment in course 185 or Computer Engineering 185. Enrollment is restricted to junior and senior bioengineering, biomolecular engineering & Bioinformatics BS, and bioinformatics majors or by permission.
BME 180 - 01 Professional Practice in Bi.title: BME 180 - 01 Professional Practice in Bioengineering

BME 80H - 01 The Human Genome.description: Course will focus on understanding human genes. Accessible to non-science majors. Will cover principles of human inheritance and techniques used in gene analysis. The evolutionary, social, ethical, and legal issues associated with knowledge of the human genome will be discussed.
BME 80H - 01 The Human Genome.title: BME 80H - 01 The Human Genome

CHEM 1A - 01 General Chemistry.description: An integrated study of general chemistry. Covers a range of topics including the atomic structure of matter; molecules; chemical reactions; acids and bases; gases; and equilibria in the gas and liquid phase. Students are  expected to use algebra to solve problems. General Chemistry is articulated in a full-year series. Partial transfer credit is not allowed for the A,B,C series.
CHEM 1A - 01 General Chemistry.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Previous or concurrent enrollment in MATH 3 (or equivalent), or a mathematics placement score of 300 or higher; taking the online chemistry self-assessment exam is strongly recommended.
CHEM 1A - 01 General Chemistry.title: CHEM 1A - 01 General Chemistry

CHIN 108 - 01 Introduction to Classical.description: Introduces the grammar and lexicon of classical Chinese and the language of China's pre-modern canonical writings in philosophy, religion, history, music, visual art, and literature. Classical poetry and lyrics are featured.
CHIN 108 - 01 Introduction to Classical.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 103 or 104 or 105 or 107; or by consent of instructor.
CHIN 108 - 01 Introduction to Classical.title: CHIN 108 - 01 Introduction to Classical Chinese Poetry

CHIN 6 - 01 Second-Year Chinese.description: Continuation of Chinese 5. Conversation, composition, and the reading of modern texts.  (Formerly Intermediate Chinese (Mandarin).)
CHIN 6 - 01 Second-Year Chinese.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or 5H or by consent of instructor.
CHIN 6 - 01 Second-Year Chinese.title: CHIN 6 - 01 Second-Year Chinese

CLNI 86 - 01 College Leadership Developm.description: Students newly appointed into leadership positions at College Nine explore the concept of leadership relating to the college's theme of  International and Global Perspectives. Prerequisite(s): current College Nine student leader; permission of instructor.
CLNI 86 - 01 College Leadership Developm.title: CLNI 86 - 01 College Leadership Development

CLTE 86 - 01 College Leadership Developm.description: Students newly appointed into leadership positions at College Ten explore the concept of leadership relating to the college's theme of Social Justice and Community. Prerequisite(s): current College Ten student leader; permission of instructor.
CLTE 86 - 01 College Leadership Developm.title: CLTE 86 - 01 College Leadership Development

CLTE 98 - 01 Alternative Spring Break.description: Provides students with the opportunity to conduct service-learning work in a local Santa Cruz community over spring break. There are four preliminary class meetings in the winter quarter.  Winter meeting attendance is required. Enrollment is by interview only. Enrollment is restricted to College Nine and College Ten members.
CLTE 98 - 01 Alternative Spring Break.title: CLTE 98 - 01 Alternative Spring Break

CMMU 156 - 01 Politics of Food and Healt.description: Critically examines contemporary debates about market and policy approaches to improve nutrition and dietary health and to address issues, such as food insecurity, obesity, and malnutrition. (Formerly Politics of Obesity.)
CMMU 156 - 01 Politics of Food and Healt.title: CMMU 156 - 01 Politics of Food and Health

CMPE 107 - 01 Probability and Statistics.description: Introduction to fundamental tools of stochastic analysis. Probability, conditional probability; Bayes Theorem; random variables and transforms; independence; Bernnoulli trials. Statistics, inference from limited data; outcomes of repeated experiments; applications to design; assessment of relative frequency and probability; law of large numbers; precision of measurements. Elements of stochastic processes, Poisson processes; Markov chains. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 131. (Formerly Mathematical Methods of Systems Analysis: Stochastic.)
CMPE 107 - 01 Probability and Statistics.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 16 or 16H and Mathematics 22 or 23A.
CMPE 107 - 01 Probability and Statistics.title: CMPE 107 - 01 Probability and Statistics for Engineers

CMPE 107 - 02 Probability and Statistics.description: Introduction to fundamental tools of stochastic analysis. Probability, conditional probability; Bayes Theorem; random variables and transforms; independence; Bernnoulli trials. Statistics, inference from limited data; outcomes of repeated experiments; applications to design; assessment of relative frequency and probability; law of large numbers; precision of measurements. Elements of stochastic processes, Poisson processes; Markov chains. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 131. (Formerly Mathematical Methods of Systems Analysis: Stochastic.)
CMPE 107 - 02 Probability and Statistics.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 16 or 16H and Mathematics 22 or 23A.
CMPE 107 - 02 Probability and Statistics.title: CMPE 107 - 02 Probability and Statistics for Engineers

CMPE 16 - 01 Applied Discrete Mathematic.description: Introduction to applications of discrete mathematical systems. Topics include sets, functions, relations, graphs, predicate calculus, mathematical proof methods (induction, contraposition, contradiction), counting methods (permutations, combinations), and recurrences. Examples are drawn from computer science and computer engineering. Knowledge of computer programming is useful before taking this course. Students who do not have prior programing experience are strongly recommended to take Computer Science 5C, 5J, or 5P before taking this course.
CMPE 16 - 01 Applied Discrete Mathematic.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 19A or 11B or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11B or 15B or Economics 11B.
CMPE 16 - 01 Applied Discrete Mathematic.title: CMPE 16 - 01 Applied Discrete Mathematics

CMPE 80N - 01 Introduction to Networking.description: Introduction to the evolution, technological basis, and services of the Internet, with descriptions of its underlying communications structure, routing algorithms, peer-to-peer hierarchy, reliability, and packet switching. Network security, mail, multimedia and data compression issues, HTML, and digital images. Students who have completed course 150 cannot receive credit for this course.
CMPE 80N - 01 Introduction to Networking.title: CMPE 80N - 01 Introduction to Networking and the Internet

CMPM 120 - 01 Game Development Experienc.description: Teaches the concrete programming and collaboration skills associated with making a digital game from start to finish, including but not limited to: establishing a team, concepting, storyboarding, prototyping, producing, and testing a game for release. Students are organized into groups and work together to create and produce a playable game. This course is taught in conjunction with Art 120G which covers the skills required to design and critique digital games.
CMPM 120 - 01 Game Development Experienc.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 80K, Computer Science 12B and 12M, and Film and Digital Media 80V; and Art and Design: Games and Playable Media (ARTG) 80G or 80H or 80I; and concurrent enrollment in ARTG 120.
CMPM 120 - 01 Game Development Experienc.title: CMPM 120 - 01 Game Development Experience

CMPS 11 - 01 Intermediate Programming.description: Continuation of course 5J. Covers basic object-oriented programming, event-driven programming, graphical user interface (GUI) creation, recursion, two-dimensional arrays. The two-quarter sequence courses 5J and 11 cover in two quarters the same material as the accelerated introductory course and lab 12A/L cover in one quarter. Students cannot receive credit this course and course 12A.
CMPS 11 - 01 Intermediate Programming.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5J, and Mathematics 3 or 11A or 19A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics/Economics 11A or a score of 400 or higher on the  mathematics placement examination (MPE).
CMPS 11 - 01 Intermediate Programming.title: CMPS 11 - 01 Intermediate Programming

CMPS 12B - 01 Introduction to Data Struc.description: Teaches students to implement common data structures and the algorithms associated with each data structure, through progressively difficult exercises. Topics include big "O" notation; pointers, recursion (induction), and dynamic allocation; linked lists and list processing; stacks, queues, binary trees and binary search trees; simple sorting techniques and simple search techniques. Students will gain a working knowledge of the elements of the Java and C programming languages. Prior experience with Unix is assumed.
CMPS 12B - 01 Introduction to Data Struc.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11 or 12A or Computer Engineering 13. Concurrent enrollment in course 12M is required.
CMPS 12B - 01 Introduction to Data Struc.title: CMPS 12B - 01 Introduction to Data Structures

CMPS 12B - 02 Introduction to Data Struc.description: Teaches students to implement common data structures and the algorithms associated with each data structure, through progressively difficult exercises. Topics include big "O" notation; pointers, recursion (induction), and dynamic allocation; linked lists and list processing; stacks, queues, binary trees and binary search trees; simple sorting techniques and simple search techniques. Students will gain a working knowledge of the elements of the Java and C programming languages. Prior experience with Unix is assumed.
CMPS 12B - 02 Introduction to Data Struc.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11 or 12A or Computer Engineering 13. Concurrent enrollment in course 12M is required.
CMPS 12B - 02 Introduction to Data Struc.title: CMPS 12B - 02 Introduction to Data Structures

CMPS 183 - 01 Web Applications.description: The World-Wde Web is one of the main mechanisms by which computer applications are delivered to users. This course introduces the design of Web applications.  Students learn the main technologies involved, and build web applications as part of homework assignments and group class projects.(Formerly Hypermedia and the Web.)
CMPS 183 - 01 Web Applications.title: CMPS 183 - 01 Web Applications

CMPS 5J - 01 Introduction to Programming.description: Introduces programming in Java for students who have no prior programming experience. Students learn programming and documentation skills, as well as algorithmic problem-solving, and programming methodologies. Introduces computers, compilers, and editors. Students write small to medium-sized programs. This course and courses 5C and 5P cover similar concepts, but use different programming languages. Because 5J followed by course 11 is a two-quarter alternative to the accelerated course 12A/L, engineering majors and students planning on continuing the programming sequence are encouraged to take 5J rather than 5C or 5P. Students may not receive credit for 5J taken concurrently or subsequently to course 12A, 12B, or Computer Engineering 13.
CMPS 5J - 01 Introduction to Programming.title: CMPS 5J - 01 Introduction to Programming in Java

CMPS 5P - 01 Introduction to Programming.description: Introduces programming in Python, a high-level programming language used in the physical and social sciences and for Internet scripting. Students learn programming and documentation skills, as well as algorithmic problem-solving, coding, and debugging methodologies. Students write programs to solve sample problems drawn from a wide range of disciplines, primarily in the sciences. No prior programming experience is required, but a mathematics background at the pre-calculus level is assumed. This course and courses 5C and 5J cover similar concepts, but use different programming languages. Students may not receive credit for course 5P after receiving credit for course 11, 12A, or Computer Engineering 13.
CMPS 5P - 01 Introduction to Programming.enrollment_requirements: Students may not enroll in or receive credit for course 5P after receiving credit with a 'C' or better in course 11, 12A, or Computer Engineering 13.
CMPS 5P - 01 Introduction to Programming.title: CMPS 5P - 01 Introduction to Programming in Python

COWL 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporar.description: Introduces the Model United Nations through discussion of contemporary issues. Students learn parliamentary procedures and U.N. protocols, as well as how to work collaboratively to research and to present position papers. Students learn resolution writing, alliance building, and persuasive speech. May be repeated for credit.
COWL 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporar.title: COWL 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporary Issues

COWL 168 - 01 Social Change.description: How do you change the world, working alone and in concert with others? To find out, students work in groups with specific community partners who, in turn, help place students in social-change organizations in Santa Cruz County. May be repeated for credit.
COWL 168 - 01 Social Change.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to college members.
COWL 168 - 01 Social Change.title: COWL 168 - 01 Social Change

COWL 184C - 01 Leadership and Institutio.description: Through lectures by senior administrators and student consensus-and-recommendation teams, students learn how leaders work with constituent groups, build cooperation, and develop implementation plans in an institution such as the University of California, specifically, UC Santa Cruz. Enrollment is restricted to undergraduates accepted in the Chancellor's Undergraduate Internship Program. Students submit applications winter quarter for the following academic year.
COWL 184C - 01 Leadership and Institutio.title: COWL 184C - 01 Leadership and Institution Building

COWL 65 - 01 Meaning, Paradox, and Love.description: Mary Holmes--legendary founding faculty member of UCSC, keen observer, painter of mythic images, and profound thinker--had a visionary's insight into the mysteries of love, paradox, and meaning. This course explores her art, teaching, and wisdom. (Formerly Love and Wisdom.)
COWL 65 - 01 Meaning, Paradox, and Love.title: COWL 65 - 01 Meaning, Paradox, and Love

CRES 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century.description: Examines the material, discursive, and racialized conditions that have produced refugees in the last century. Also examines the social claims made by refugees, institutional responses to them, and political alternatives to state belonging
CRES 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century.title: CRES 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century: Non-Citizens and Modernity

CRES 45 - 01 Pilipinx Historical Dialogu.description: Examines the history, politics, and cultural expressions of the Pilipinx community, in the Philippines and the diaspora, with an emphasis on Pilipinx and Pilipinx-American activism.
CRES 45 - 01 Pilipinx Historical Dialogu.title: CRES 45 - 01 Pilipinx Historical Dialogue

CRSN 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporar.description: Introduces the Model United Nations through discussion of contemporary issues. Students learn parliamentary procedures and U.N. protocols, as well as how to work collaboratively to research and to present position papers. Students learn resolution writing, alliance building, and persuasive speech. May be repeated for credit.
CRSN 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporar.title: CRSN 122 - 01 United Nations Contemporary Issues

CRSN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.description: Critically interrogates the multiple meanings of "data" and "democracy." Students examine case studies on the mobilization and framing of "democracy" in particular moments. Students also analyze concerns and opportunities provided by "data" management and archival practices of evidence and cataloging.
CRSN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.title: CRSN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy

CRSN 55 - 01 Rachel Carson College: Serv.description: Introduces service-learning theory and practice for students engaging in service-learning work in the college, college-related projects, community service organizations, or public agencies. May be repeated for credit.
CRSN 55 - 01 Rachel Carson College: Serv.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment restricted to college members until after priority enrollment.
CRSN 55 - 01 Rachel Carson College: Serv.title: CRSN 55 - 01 Rachel Carson College: Service Learning Practicum

CRWN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.description: Critically interrogates the multiple meanings of "data" and "democracy." Students examine case studies on the mobilization and framing of "democracy" in particular moments. Students also analyze concerns and opportunities provided by "data" management and archival practices of evidence and cataloging.
CRWN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.title: CRWN 175S - 01 Data and Democracy

CRWN 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Chang.description: Students in this course explore and discuss the applicability of the Social Change Model of Leadership Development (Wagner, 1996) within the immediate UCSC, Crown College, and Merrill College communities. Students draw connections between concepts of leadership, community development, and community service. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. Students must have a leadership role (e.g., R.A., student government) with Crown College or Merrill College.
CRWN 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Chang.title: CRWN 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Change

CRWN 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Chang.description: Students in this course explore and discuss the applicability of the Social Change Model of Leadership Development (Wagner, 1996) within the immediate UCSC, Crown College, and Merrill College communities. Students draw connections between concepts of leadership, community development, and community service. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. Students must have a leadership role (e.g., R.A., student government) with Crown College or Merrill College.
CRWN 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Chang.title: CRWN 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Change

CRWN 70L - 01 Broadcast Production: Radi.description: Practical application of technical and creative skills in the KZSC studios. Production of audio content and promotional materials for broadcast. Critical evaluation in a workshop setting. Assignments require original research, professional writing, and the operation of complex technology. Prerequisite(s): After completing 20 hours of orientation volunteering at KZSC, students apply to the instructor. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. Concurrent enrollment in course 70 is required.
CRWN 70L - 01 Broadcast Production: Radi.title: CRWN 70L - 01 Broadcast Production: Radio

CRWN 80F - 01 Science Fictions.description: Examines how science fictions have imagined better and worse worlds, social relations, and identities by using science and technology. Students read novels and short stories from the 19th Century to the present and discuss and debate questions of justice, freedom, difference, and identity.  (Formerly "Seminar in Science Fiction.")
CRWN 80F - 01 Science Fictions.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing requirement.
CRWN 80F - 01 Science Fictions.title: CRWN 80F - 01 Science Fictions

EART 106 - 01 Coasts in Crisis.description: Comprehensive assessment of the impacts that the human population is having on the coastal zone globally and the diverse ways in which geologic processes and coastal hazards impact human settlement and development in the coastal zone.
EART 106 - 01 Coasts in Crisis.title: EART 106 - 01 Coasts in Crisis

EART 109L - 01 Field Geology Laboratory.description: Laboratory exercises essential to the successful completion of fieldwork required in course 109. Topics include topographic maps, Brunton compass, rock identification and description, geologic map analysis, structure section "construction," and landslide recognition.
EART 109L - 01 Field Geology Laboratory.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or 10 or 20, and 5L or 10L or 20L. Enrollment is restricted to majors and minors in Earth and planetary sciences and the combined majors with anthropology and environmental studies or by permission of instructor.
EART 109L - 01 Field Geology Laboratory.title: EART 109L - 01 Field Geology Laboratory

EART 109L - 02 Field Geology Laboratory.description: Laboratory exercises essential to the successful completion of fieldwork required in course 109. Topics include topographic maps, Brunton compass, rock identification and description, geologic map analysis, structure section "construction," and landslide recognition.
EART 109L - 02 Field Geology Laboratory.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or 10 or 20, and 5L or 10L or 20L. Enrollment is restricted to majors and minors in Earth and planetary sciences and the combined majors with anthropology and environmental studies or by permission of instructor.
EART 109L - 02 Field Geology Laboratory.title: EART 109L - 02 Field Geology Laboratory

EART 20 - 01 Environmental Geology.description: Introduction to aspects of geology which affect and are affected by humans. Addresses a broad range of topics including resource management, geologic hazards, air and water issues, population and land use, energy costs and effectiveness, and global change,  all from a unique geological/environmental perspective. Lectures include strategies for mitigating these issues. Includes a one-day field trip. Concurrent enrollment in 20L required for majors and minors.
EART 20 - 01 Environmental Geology.title: EART 20 - 01 Environmental Geology

EART 3 - 01 Geology of National Parks.description: Geologic concepts and processes responsible for shaping our national parks including mountain building, volcanic and earthquake activity, sedimentation, weathering, erosion, and glaciation. An understanding of how geology impacts our lives is emphasized. Appropriate for both science and non-science majors who wish to enhance their knowledge, enjoyment, and appreciation of our national parks.
EART 3 - 01 Geology of National Parks.title: EART 3 - 01 Geology of National Parks

EART 30 - 01 Water in the Environment.description: Broadly explores how components of the water cycle (precipitation, evapotranspiration, streamflow, groundwater) influence the structure of different environments as well as the communities, cultures, and people within these environments.
EART 30 - 01 Water in the Environment.title: EART 30 - 01 Water in the Environment

EART 8 - 01 Planetary Discovery.description: A sweeping tour of planets, satellites, and small bodies in and out of the solar system. Focuses on major scientific results from telescopes and spacecraft missions. Topics include planetary system architecture, planetary atmosphere, surface and interior, planetary formation and evolution, astrobiology, extra-solar planets. Open to all students.
EART 8 - 01 Planetary Discovery.title: EART 8 - 01 Planetary Discovery

ECON 1 - 01 Introductory Microeconomics:.description: For all interested students as well as prospective economics majors. Examines how markets allocate resources in different kinds of economies. Topics include competitive markets, monopoly, financial markets, income distribution, market failures, the environment, and the role of government.
ECON 1 - 01 Introductory Microeconomics:.title: ECON 1 - 01 Introductory Microeconomics: Resource Allocation and Market Structure

ECON 113 - 01 Introduction to Econometri.description: Practical methods for organizing and analyzing economic data, testing economic hypotheses, and measuring economic relationships. Regression analysis is the main empirical method, and basic statistical and probability theory is included. Students gain hands-on computer experience with an econometric software package. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 113.
ECON 113 - 01 Introduction to Econometri.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 1 and 2; Applied Mathematics and Statistics 5 or 7; and one of the following: course 11B, Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11B, Mathematics 22, or Mathematics 23A. Courses 100A or 100B strongly recommended as preparation.
ECON 113 - 01 Introduction to Econometri.title: ECON 113 - 01 Introduction to Econometrics

ECON 113 - 02 Introduction to Econometri.description: Practical methods for organizing and analyzing economic data, testing economic hypotheses, and measuring economic relationships. Regression analysis is the main empirical method, and basic statistical and probability theory is included. Students gain hands-on computer experience with an econometric software package. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 113.
ECON 113 - 02 Introduction to Econometri.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 1 and 2; Applied Mathematics and Statistics 5 or 7; and one of the following: course 11B, Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11B, Mathematics 22, or Mathematics 23A. Courses 100A or 100B strongly recommended as preparation.
ECON 113 - 02 Introduction to Econometri.title: ECON 113 - 02 Introduction to Econometrics

ECON 116 - 01 Advanced Topics in Account.description: Covers topics in accounting and ethics. Builds a strong accounting foundation; develops critical thinking skills; and explores ethical standards in accounting, forensic accounting, international financial recording standards, and accounting for sustainability. Meets the California state educational ethics requirement for certified public accountant (CPA) licensure.
ECON 116 - 01 Advanced Topics in Account.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 111A and 111B. Enrollment is restricted to economics, business management economics, global economics, and the combined economics and environmental studies and mathematics majors.
ECON 116 - 01 Advanced Topics in Account.title: ECON 116 - 01 Advanced Topics in Accounting and Ethics

ECON 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.description: Introduction to mathematical tools and reasoning, with applications to economics. Topics are drawn from differential calculus in one variable and include limits, continuity, differentiation, elasticity, Taylor polynomials, and optimization. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and Mathematics 11A or 19A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15A. (Also offered as Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A. Students cannot receive credit for both courses.)
ECON 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.enrollment_requirements: Students who have already taken Mathematics 11A or 19A should not take this course. Prerequisite(s): score of 300 or higher on the mathematics placement examination (MPE), Applied Math and Statistics 2, 3, or 6, or Mathematics 3.
ECON 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.title: ECON 11A - 01 Mathematical Methods for Economists I

ECON 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.description: Mathematical tools and reasoning, with applications to economics. Topics are drawn from multivariable differential calculus and single variable integral calculus, and include partial derivatives, linear and quadratic approximation, optimization with and without constraints, Lagrange multipliers, definite and indefinite integrals, and elementary differential equations. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and Mathematics 11B or 19B or Applied Math and Statistics 15B.
ECON 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11A, or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A, or Mathematics 11A, or Mathematics 19A.
ECON 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for E.title: ECON 11B - 01 Mathematical Methods for Economists II

ECON 2 - 01 Introductory Macroeconomics:.description: For all interested students and prospective economics majors. Examines how the overall level of national economic activity is determined, including output, employment, and inflation. Explores the roles of monetary and fiscal policies in stabilizing the economy and promoting growth, with a focus on contemporary policy debates.
ECON 2 - 01 Introductory Macroeconomics:.title: ECON 2 - 01 Introductory Macroeconomics: Aggregate Economic Activity

EDUC 128 - 01 Immigrants and Education.description: Research and theory on the education of immigrant students. Major topics include the Americanization movement and America's changing demography, identity maintenance and change, home-school relations, and educators' roles in meeting the needs of culturally and linguistically diverse student populations.
EDUC 128 - 01 Immigrants and Education.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to education or STEM minors, physics education majors, or students with math education concentration or Earth sciences science education concentration, or biology B.A. bioeducation, or by permission of instructor.
EDUC 128 - 01 Immigrants and Education.title: EDUC 128 - 01 Immigrants and Education

EDUC 177 - 01 Teaching Culturally and Li.description: Examines equity issues in the learning and teaching of math and science in culturally and linguistically diverse school settings. Draws on multicultural, bilingual, and math/science education perspectives. Intended for undergraduate majors considering a K–12 teaching career. Satisfies an elective requirement for the minor in education program. Prior completion of course 180 is advised.
EDUC 177 - 01 Teaching Culturally and Li.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to education or STEM minors, physics education majors, or students with math education concentration or Earth sciences science education concentration, or biology B.A. bioeducation, or by permission of instructor.
EDUC 177 - 01 Teaching Culturally and Li.title: EDUC 177 - 01 Teaching Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Students Math and Science

EE 180J - 01 Advanced Renewable Energy S.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of renewable energy, storage, and smart grids. Fundamental energy-conversion limits based on physics and existing material properties are discussed. Various sources and facilities, such as solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, tidal energy, and fuel cells are described. Solar- and wind-site assessment, electric vehicles, as well as sustainable microgrids are also discussed. Finally, the latest research on smart grids and smart cities is introduced. Taught in conjunction with course 80J. (Formerly Advanced Renewable Energy Sources.)
EE 180J - 01 Advanced Renewable Energy S.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 3 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3, 5 or 7.
EE 180J - 01 Advanced Renewable Energy S.title: EE 180J - 01 Advanced Renewable Energy Sources, Storage, and Smart Grids

EE 80J - 01 Renewable Energy Sources, St.description: Introduces energy sources and storage with special emphasis on renewables as part of smart grids. Fundamental energy-conversion limits based on physics and existing source properties are studied. Various sources, such as solar, wind, hydropower, geothermal, tidal energy, and fuel cells are described. Electric vehicles, sustainable microgrids, and the integration to smart grids are studied. Finally, smart meters, demand response, the energy market, and policy are covered. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 81J.  (Formerly Renewable Energy Sources.)
EE 80J - 01 Renewable Energy Sources, St.title: EE 80J - 01 Renewable Energy Sources, Storage, and Smart Grids

ENVS 100L - 01 Ecology and Society Writi.description: Required writing lab accompanying course 100. Students are introduced to writing in different styles and for different audiences typical of the ecosystem-society interface.  Course 100 writing assignments are developed, written, and revised in conjunction with the lab.  W credit is granted only upon successful completion of course 100.
ENVS 100L - 01 Ecology and Society Writi.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 23 or CHEM 1A; course 24 or BIOE 20C; course 25; and AMS 7/L or ECON 113 or OCEA 90; and one from: ANTH 2, SOCY 1,10,15, PHIL 21,22,24,28, or 80G.  Satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
ENVS 100L - 01 Ecology and Society Writi.title: ENVS 100L - 01 Ecology and Society Writing Laboratory

Satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
ENVS 100L - 06 Ecology and Society Writi.title: ENVS 100L - 06 Ecology and Society Writing Laboratory

ENVS 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.description: A survey of the diversity, structure, and functioning of California's ecosystems through time and the ways they have influenced and responded to human activities and stewardship. Topics include: ecosystem drivers such as climate, soils, and land-use history; human and ecological prehistory; comparative marine, freshwater, and terrestrial ecosystem dynamics; and managed ecosystems such as range, fisheries, and agriculture.
ENVS 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): previous or concurrent enrollment in courses 100 and 100L.
ENVS 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California.title: ENVS 125 - 01 Ecosystems of California

ENVS 176 - 01 Vulnerability, Complex Sys.description: Introduces students to the research on the relationship between vulnerability and disasters, and on complex systems including hazardous technologies. Explores perspectives on disasters in the literature on political ecology. Also examines relevant work of organizational sociology, and related fields including normal accident and high reliability organizational theories.
ENVS 176 - 01 Vulnerability, Complex Sys.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Previous or concurrent enrollment in courses 100 and 100L, or by permission of the instructor.
ENVS 176 - 01 Vulnerability, Complex Sys.title: ENVS 176 - 01 Vulnerability, Complex Systems, and Disasters

ESCI 160 - 01 Data Analysis in the Envir.description: Introduces data-analysis methods regularly encountered within environmental sciences. Students learn how to think about data, its uncertainty, how models and data are related and depend on underlying assumptions, and how to synthesize information contained in data.
ESCI 160 - 01 Data Analysis in the Envir.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 11B or equivalent. Enrollment is restricted to environmental sciences majors.
ESCI 160 - 01 Data Analysis in the Envir.title: ESCI 160 - 01 Data Analysis in the Environmental Sciences

FILM 134B - 01 American Film, 1960-Prese.description: A survey of American narrative cinema from 1960 to the present. Examines developments in film style, film technology, and the film industry in relation to American cultural history. Students are billed a course materials fee.
FILM 134B - 01 American Film, 1960-Prese.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 20A or 20B; and satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
FILM 134B - 01 American Film, 1960-Prese.title: FILM 134B - 01 American Film, 1960-Present

FILM 136B - 01 History of Television.description: Survey of the historical development of broadcast television from its origins to the present day phenomena of cable, satellite, and electronic networks. Examination of major genres, forms, and modes of production and consumption within cultural, social, and economic contexts. Offered every other year, alternating with course 136A. Students are billed a course materials fee.
FILM 136B - 01 History of Television.title: FILM 136B - 01 History of Television

FILM 150 - 01 Screenwriting.description: Problems in writing for film and television are explored through the writing of original material and analysis of existing works. Various film genres, conventions, and styles, both fictional and nonfictional, are examined. Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements; priority given to students in the production concentration. Admission by application; application materials available during the last three weeks of preceding quarter. Students not in the production concentration but have completed the Entry Level Writing and Composition prerequisites may apply and will be considered if space is available. May be repeated for credit.
FILM 150 - 01 Screenwriting.title: FILM 150 - 01 Screenwriting

FILM 165B - 01 Race on Screen.description: Review of historical and critical tools to interpret representations of race on cinematic, television, and computer screens. Class will consider the place of race in theoretical and historical scholarship and examine the debates about race produced within and across film and digital media. Students are billed a course materials fee. Usually offered in alternate academic years.
FILM 165B - 01 Race on Screen.title: FILM 165B - 01 Race on Screen

FILM 165D - 01 Asian Americans and Media.description: Examines media representations about, as well as by, Asian Americans. Using critical essays on film theory, racial studies, feminist criticism, and independent cinema, students develop the skills necessary to conduct critical analysis of Asian Americans in film and television. Students are billed a course materials fee.
FILM 165D - 01 Asian Americans and Media.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 20A. Enrollment is restricted to sophomores,  juniors, and seniors.
FILM 165D - 01 Asian Americans and Media.title: FILM 165D - 01 Asian Americans and Media

FILM 168 - 01 National Cinema and Cultur.description: Study of a specific cinematic or other media tradition of a region, nation, language, diasporic collectivity or other unifying cultural entity. Not a survey, this course selects one focus or offers a comparative of cross-cultural framework. Students are billed a course materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
FILM 168 - 01 National Cinema and Cultur.title: FILM 168 - 01 National Cinema and Culture

FILM 170A - 01 Fundamentals of Digital M.description: Introduction to the conceptual and technical fundamentals of making digital media. Covers principles of digital image manipulation, basic web authoring, and interface design through projects that introduce production techniques and methods. Students are billed a course materials fee.
FILM 170A - 01 Fundamentals of Digital M.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 20C or Computer Science 101 or Computer Science 109.
FILM 170A - 01 Fundamentals of Digital M.title: FILM 170A - 01 Fundamentals of Digital Media Production

FILM 170B - 01 Fundamentals of Film and.description: An introduction to the art and craft of making films and videos. Covers principles of cinematography, videography, editing, production planning, and lighting involving both production techniques and methods. Students are billed a course materials fee. Prerequisite(s): course 20A or 20B and at least one upper-division film and digital media critical studies course. Admission by application; application materials available during the last three weeks of preceding quarter.
FILM 170B - 01 Fundamentals of Film and.title: FILM 170B - 01 Fundamentals of Film and Video Production

FILM 170B - 02 Fundamentals of Film and.description: An introduction to the art and craft of making films and videos. Covers principles of cinematography, videography, editing, production planning, and lighting involving both production techniques and methods. Students are billed a course materials fee. Prerequisite(s): course 20A or 20B and at least one upper-division film and digital media critical studies course. Admission by application; application materials available during the last three weeks of preceding quarter.
FILM 170B - 02 Fundamentals of Film and.title: FILM 170B - 02 Fundamentals of Film and Video Production

FILM 171C - 01 Special Topics Workshop:.description: Students will consider the practice of "recycling" images perhaps not intended by the original "owner" or "creator." In addition to assigned readings and technical workshops, students produce three video projects and give a presentation on a specific issue or artist/group. Prerequisite(s): course 170A or 170B; priority given to students in the production concentration. Admission by application; application materials available during the last three weeks of preceding quarter. Students not in the production concentration but have completed 170A or 170B may apply and will be considered if space is available.
FILM 171C - 01 Special Topics Workshop:.title: FILM 171C - 01 Special Topics Workshop: Found Footage

FILM 20P - 01 Introduction to Production.description: Introduction to the production processes of visual/aural, time-based, creative work. Students work on a range of creative projects: performed, written, photographed, and created digitally. Assignments emphasize imaginative problem-solving, collaboration, visualization, and critical media literacy. Students are billed a course materials fee.
FILM 20P - 01 Introduction to Production.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Course 20A or 20B or 20C or 80A or 80M.  Enrollment is restricted to pre-majors, proposed majors, majors, frosh, sophomores, juniors, and students not currently declared in the production concentration.
FILM 20P - 01 Introduction to Production.title: FILM 20P - 01 Introduction to Production Technique

FILM 80S - 01 Special Topics in Film and.description: Study of selected aspects of film, television, and/or digital media. Includes weekly screenings and historical/theoretical readings. May be repeated for credit.
FILM 80S - 01 Special Topics in Film and.title: FILM 80S - 01 Special Topics in Film and Digital Media

FMST 145 - 01 Racial and Gender Formatio.description: Introduces the defining issues surrounding racial and gender formations in the U.S. through an understanding of the term "women of color" as an emergent, dynamic, and socio-political phenomenon. Interrogates organizing practices around women of color across multiple sites: film and media, globalization, representation, sexuality, historiography, and war, to name a select few.
FMST 145 - 01 Racial and Gender Formatio.title: FMST 145 - 01 Racial and Gender Formations in the U.S

FMST 16 - 01 Media Histories--News and N.description: The news is a set of narratives that produce, maintain, repair, and transform reality. Using three events that brought together "old" and "new" media, this course traces how the interaction of new media with news has changed how we make sense of the world around us and our place in it.
FMST 16 - 01 Media Histories--News and N.title: FMST 16 - 01 Media Histories--News and New Media

FMST 30 - 01 Feminism and Science.description: Explores questions of science and justice. Examines the nature of scientific practice, the culture of science, and the possibilities for the responsible practice of science. Rather than focusing on feminist critiques of science, the course examines how science and technology are changing our world and the workings of power.  (Formerly course 80K.)
FMST 30 - 01 Feminism and Science.title: FMST 30 - 01 Feminism and Science

FREN 4 - 01 Second-Year French.description: First course in intermediate sequence. Students review and expand upon their previous study of the language through short literary readings, vocabulary building, grammar study, composition, and discussions. (Formerly Intermediate French.)
FREN 4 - 01 Second-Year French.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s):  course 3 or placement by interview.
FREN 4 - 01 Second-Year French.title: FREN 4 - 01 Second-Year French

FREN 6 - 01 Second-Year French.description: Final course of intermediate sequence includes grammar study, vocabulary building, extensive writing, and discussion. Reading of a French or Francophone novel is an integral part of course.
FREN 6 - 01 Second-Year French.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or placement by interview.
FREN 6 - 01 Second-Year French.title: FREN 6 - 01 Second-Year French

GERM 119 - 01 German Media.description: This third-year language and culture course is designed for students who are comfortable speaking and writing German at the German 5 level or above. Using a variety of German media sources, students give oral presentations and write reports on contemporary issues. Taught in German. May be repeated for credit.
GERM 119 - 01 German Media.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or placement by examination.
GERM 119 - 01 German Media.title: GERM 119 - 01 German Media

GERM 6 - 01 Second-Year German.description: Intermediate composition and conversation based on the reading of selected prose and related cultural material. Speaking, reading, writing, and listening comprehension skills are developed by extensive use of media materials. Conducted entirely in German.
GERM 6 - 01 Second-Year German.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or placement by examination.
GERM 6 - 01 Second-Year German.title: GERM 6 - 01 Second-Year German

HAVC 110 - 01 Visual Cultures of West Af.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 110 - 01 Visual Cultures of West Af.description: Explores visual cultures of West Africa through time (Nok to present). Attention paid to relationships between peoples and impact of European/Arab presence on visual cultures. Prerequisite(s): course 10 or 80 recommended.
HAVC 110 - 01 Visual Cultures of West Af.title: HAVC 110 - 01 Visual Cultures of West Africa

HAVC 140C - 01 Race and American Visual.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 140C - 01 Race and American Visual.description: Investigation of the role played by  visual arts in fashioning the racial identities of European-Americans, African Americans, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and Latinos in the United States.
HAVC 140C - 01 Race and American Visual.title: HAVC 140C - 01 Race and American Visual Arts

HAVC 140D - 01 Chicano/Chicana Art: 1970.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 140D - 01 Chicano/Chicana Art: 1970.description: Taking the terms "Chicano" and "Chicana" as a critical framework, addresses cultural and conceptual themes in visual art production since 1970. Questions concerning aesthetics, identity, gender, and activism in painting, photography, murals, and installation art explored.
HAVC 140D - 01 Chicano/Chicana Art: 1970.title: HAVC 140D - 01 Chicano/Chicana Art: 1970-Present

HAVC 141E - 01 Histories of Photography.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 141E - 01 Histories of Photography.description: Introduction to the histories of photography and the critical debates around different photographic genres such as medical photography, art photography, and political photography. Students will develop a critical language in order to analyze photographs while considering the importance of social and institutional contexts.
HAVC 141E - 01 Histories of Photography.title: HAVC 141E - 01 Histories of Photography

HAVC 179 - 01 Topics in Oceanic Visual C.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 179 - 01 Topics in Oceanic Visual C.description: Examines selected and changing topics in the study of oceanic visual culture. The specific topic varies with each offering in order to keep up with recent directions in scholarship. Possible topics include: archaeological material and visual cultures; colonial-era images, objects, and spaces; architecture and environments; performance; gender; race and ethnicity; modern/contemporary art and visual culture; and/or a regional focus. May be repeated for credit.
HAVC 179 - 01 Topics in Oceanic Visual C.title: HAVC 179 - 01 Topics in Oceanic Visual Culture

HAVC 190J - 01 Visual Cultures of the Vi.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 190J - 01 Visual Cultures of the Vi.description: Examines the visual culture of the Vietnam-American war and its legacy in contemporary art of Southeast Asia. Considers representations in different media: painting, drawing, photography, film, novels, and material cultures. Issues addressed include memory, trauma, identity politics, body, race, gender, pornography, and prostitution.
HAVC 190J - 01 Visual Cultures of the Vi.title: HAVC 190J - 01 Visual Cultures of the Vietnam-American War

HAVC 22 - 01 Religion and Visual Culture.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 22 - 01 Religion and Visual Culture.description: Introduction to the study of religious currents and practices in China and their visual expression. In addition to "religious art,"  topics include such pivotal matters as body concepts and practices, representations of the natural world, and logics of the built environment. (Formerly course 80G.)
HAVC 22 - 01 Religion and Visual Culture.title: HAVC 22 - 01 Religion and Visual Culture in China

HAVC 49 - 01 From Memes to Metadata: an.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 49 - 01 From Memes to Metadata: an.description: Introduction to digital visual culture including critical and historical approaches to memes; social media and politics; and the many intersections of data, images, and society. Sample topics include: digital art, digital activism, and surveillance. (Formerly A Short History of the Digital.)
HAVC 49 - 01 From Memes to Metadata: an.title: HAVC 49 - 01 From Memes to Metadata: an Introduction to Digital Visual Culture

HAVC 55 - 01 Unclothed: The Naked Body f.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 55 - 01 Unclothed: The Naked Body f.description: The human body without clothing in European and European-American art and visual culture from ancient Greece to the present day. Among the themes to be addressed: gender, youth and age, sexuality and sexual preference, fecundity and potency, erotic art and pornography, primitivism and the naked body of the non-European. (Formerly course 31, The Nude in the Western Tradition.)
HAVC 55 - 01 Unclothed: The Naked Body f.title: HAVC 55 - 01 Unclothed: The Naked Body from Antiquity to the Present

HAVC 80 - 01 Colonial Histories and Lega.department: History of Art and Visual Culture
HAVC 80 - 01 Colonial Histories and Lega.description: The arts and visual cultures of selected cultures that developed outside the spheres of influence of major European and Asian civilizations, with an emphasis on the history and influence of colonialism in creating current ethnic and racial categories.
HAVC 80 - 01 Colonial Histories and Lega.title: HAVC 80 - 01 Colonial Histories and Legacies: Africa, Oceania, and the Indigenous Americas

HEBR 80 - 01 Introduction to Biblical He.description: Introduces students to the basic lexicon and grammatical structures of biblical Hebrew, with an emphasis on the development of a set of useful translation strategies. Throughout the course, students apply their emergent skills to translating a variety of biblical texts.
HEBR 80 - 01 Introduction to Biblical He.title: HEBR 80 - 01 Introduction to Biblical Hebrew

HIS 100 - 01 Historical Skills and Metho.description: Designed to introduce history majors to historical methods and provide preparation for exit seminars. Students develop critical reading, historical analysis, research, and disciplinary writing skills.
HIS 100 - 01 Historical Skills and Metho.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to history majors and proposed majors or by permission of the instructor.
HIS 100 - 01 Historical Skills and Metho.title: HIS 100 - 01 Historical Skills and Methods

HIS 104C - 01 Celluloid Natives: America.description: Examines how American Indian history and culture has been portrayed in Hollywood films, with an emphasis on films that represent Native Americans over the broad spectrum of Native American/white relations.
HIS 104C - 01 Celluloid Natives: America.title: HIS 104C - 01 Celluloid Natives: American Indian History on Film

HIS 105 - 01 Nations and Nationalism.description: Provides an historical, comparative, and theoretical exploration of the development of nations and nationalism. Emphases include the historical formation of nation-states, modernization, colonialism, decolonization, nations and globalization, and the intersections between ethnicity, race, religions, and nationalism.
HIS 105 - 01 Nations and Nationalism.title: HIS 105 - 01 Nations and Nationalism

HIS 10B - 01 United States History, 1877.description: Surveys the political, social, and cultural history of the United States from 1877 to 1977. Focuses on national politics with emphasis on how class, race, ethnicity, and gender changed the nation's agenda.NOTE: This course satisfies the American History and Institutions requirement.
HIS 10B - 01 United States History, 1877.title: HIS 10B - 01 United States History, 1877 to 1977

HIS 121A - 01 African American History t.description: A survey of pre-contact Africa, indigenous social structures, class relations, the encounter with Europe, forced migration, seasoning, resistance, Africa's gift to America, slavery and its opponents, industrialization, emigration vs. assimilation, stratification, Convention Movement, Black feminism, Civil War, and Reconstruction.
HIS 121A - 01 African American History t.title: HIS 121A - 01 African American History to 1877

HIS 134B - 01 History of Mexico, 1850 to.description: Social, cultural, economic, and political history from the triumph of Liberalism to the present day, focusing on four key periods: the dictatorship of Porfirio Diaz (1900–1910), the armed phase of the Revolution (1910–1920), the consolidation of revolutionary programs and a "single-party democracy" (1920–1940), and the developmentalist counter-revolution since 1940. Provides background for understanding the Mexican diaspora to the U.S.
HIS 134B - 01 History of Mexico, 1850 to.title: HIS 134B - 01 History of Mexico, 1850 to Present
