HIS 140E - 01 Women in China's Long 20th.description: Introduces changes in Chinese women's lives--and changes in shared social ideas about what women should do and be--from the mid-19th century to the present. When we foreground gender as a category of analysis, how does history look different?
HIS 140E - 01 Women in China's Long 20th.title: HIS 140E - 01 Women in China's Long 20th Century

HIS 141B - 01 Classical Chinese Culture.description: Survey of writing and culture from the Tang through early Ming dynasties (sixth century C.E. through 16th century C.E.). Themes include literary, religious, and philosophical innovation; courtly life; cultural contacts with non-Chinese people; and transformations of state and society.  Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories. Distribution requirements: Global, Poetry,  Pre-1750.
HIS 141B - 01 Classical Chinese Culture.title: HIS 141B - 01 Classical Chinese Culture and Literature, Sixth Century through 16th Century

HIS 15 - 01 The United States of America.description: Takes students through five critical "moments" in United States history: the American Revolution, the Civil War, the New Deal, the Civil Rights era, and the years following the attack on the United States on Sept. 11, 2001.  Designed for non-majors.NOTE: This course satisfies the American History and Institutions requirement.
HIS 15 - 01 The United States of America.title: HIS 15 - 01 The United States of America from its Founding through Our Time

HIS 154 - 01 Post-Colonial North Africa.description: Introduces the history of modern North Africa from WWI to the so-called "Arab Spring." Topics include the dynamics of colonial rule and reform, anti-colonial nationalism, decolonization, the rise of Islamism, and popular protest.
HIS 154 - 01 Post-Colonial North Africa.title: HIS 154 - 01 Post-Colonial North Africa

HIS 167B - 01 The Second World War in Eu.description: Making use of multiple perspectives, this course explores the origins of the Second World War, its course and outcome, and its transformative effects on European society, culture, polities, and demographics. Closely examines the war's impact on diverse civilian populations.
HIS 167B - 01 The Second World War in Eu.title: HIS 167B - 01 The Second World War in Europe

HIS 173B - 01 Imperial Russia, 1696-1917.description: Russian history from Peter the Great through the collapse of the Russian Empire. Explores the relationship between state and subjects (both Russian and non-Russian), alongside the role that geography played in an expanding empire in an increasingly globalizing world.
HIS 173B - 01 Imperial Russia, 1696-1917.title: HIS 173B - 01 Imperial Russia, 1696-1917

HIS 185C - 01 Communism, Nationalism, an.description: Comparative in approach, course examines Jewish radical politics across Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and the Americas in the late 19th and 20th centuries. How did radical politics afford Jews greater agency in contexts that otherwise excluded them? What tensions arose with religious, nationalist, and internationalist obligations? What drew so many Jews across so many diverse contexts to focus on radical leftist politics? What, if anything, links Jews and radical politics across such diverse contexts? Through primary sources, memoirs, scholarly works, films and more, students compare Jewish engagement in radical leftist movements in several nodes, including Russia (and the former USSR), Poland, France, Egypt, Iraq, Morocco, Israel, Argentina, Mexico, and the USA among others.
HIS 185C - 01 Communism, Nationalism, an.title: HIS 185C - 01 Communism, Nationalism, and Zionism: Comparative Radical Jewish Politics

HIS 44 - 01 Modern South Asia, 1500 to P.description: Provides an introductory survey of South Asian history and society from the beginning of the 16th Century until the dawn of the 21st Century. Students gain an understanding of major events and long transformations in society, economy, culture, and politics.
HIS 44 - 01 Modern South Asia, 1500 to P.title: HIS 44 - 01 Modern South Asia, 1500 to Present

HIS 59 - 01 The History of the English L.description: Students acquire an understanding of the history of the development of the English language, from its origins to present, and engage critically with the quantitative evidence for that history, using accessible online databases and digital texts.
HIS 59 - 01 The History of the English L.title: HIS 59 - 01 The History of the English Language

HIS 76 - 01 The Holocaust.description: Investigates the genocide of the Jews from 1933 to 1945 within its broader historical context, including anti-Semitism, the Great Depression, Nazi-Soviet relations, and World War II. Examines how the Holocaust unfolded in Europe as well as its impact on Jews in North Africa and the Middle East. (Formerly Hitler and the Holocaust.)
HIS 76 - 01 The Holocaust.title: HIS 76 - 01 The Holocaust

HIS 9 - 01 Introduction to Native Americ.description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Native American Studies and the Indigenous experience. Topics include: history of United States-Indian relations; colonialism; sovereignty; identity; representation of Native Americans in popular culture; and contemporary efforts toward decolonization in indigenous communities. (Formerly Introduction to Native American Studies.)
HIS 9 - 01 Introduction to Native Americ.title: HIS 9 - 01 Introduction to Native American History

HISC 115 - 01 The Radical Right, A Sympt.description: Provides the historical context and the theoretical tools necessary for understanding today's radical right. Specific focus on considering the far right in the context of radical constructions under conditions of late capitalism.
HISC 115 - 01 The Radical Right, A Sympt.title: HISC 115 - 01 The Radical Right, A Symptom of Capitalism

HISC 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century.description: Examines the material, discursive, and racialized conditions that have produced refugees in the last century. Also examines the social claims made by refugees, institutional responses to them, and political alternatives to state belonging
HISC 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century.title: HISC 117 - 01 Making the Refugee Century: Non-Citizens and Modernity

ITAL 106 - 01 Italian Culture Through Fi.description: Film is used as a medium through which images of Italians and their culture are disseminated, perpetuated, and crystallized. Students focus on pivotal issues in Italian culture, society, history, and politics, and develop an informed opinion on relevant issues in Italian studies. The course is taught in English with a mandatory enhancement section in Italian. The enhancement section meets once a week and is designed to give students who are already familiar with the language the opportunity to  discuss the films in Italian and to read/view additional material in the language. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Italian 80 (formerly Languages 80D). May be repeated for credit.
ITAL 106 - 01 Italian Culture Through Fi.title: ITAL 106 - 01 Italian Culture Through Film

ITAL 6 - 01 Second-Year Italian.description: Reading of first novel in the language and weekly viewing of Italian films serve as basis for oral reports and discussions on various aspects of Italian culture and civilization. Weekly assignments, three essays, and a paper on topics derived from or related to the text. Students interested in this course who have not taken the prerequisite at UCSC should meet with the instructor, preferably prior to the first class meeting, and take the placement examination.
ITAL 6 - 01 Second-Year Italian.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or placement by examination.
ITAL 6 - 01 Second-Year Italian.title: ITAL 6 - 01 Second-Year Italian

ITAL 80 - 01 Italian Culture Through Cin.description: Film is used as a medium through which images of Italians and their culture are disseminated, perpetuated, and crystallized. Whether these representations offer historical perspectives or stereotypes, they are important documents for the study of Italian culture, society, history, and politics.  Students cannot receive credit for this course and Italian 106. (Formerly Languages 80D.) May be repeated for credit.
ITAL 80 - 01 Italian Culture Through Cin.title: ITAL 80 - 01 Italian Culture Through Cinema

JAPN 105 - 01 Advanced Japanese.description: Students carry out advanced-level tasks that involve listening, speaking, reading, and/or writing, and learn how to read and write 100 additional kanji. Further development of cultural knowledge and understanding through critical examination of authentic Japanese materials in a variety of genres, including literary work, expository writing, and films. May be repeated for credit with consent of instructor.
JAPN 105 - 01 Advanced Japanese.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 104 or by consent of instructor.
JAPN 105 - 01 Advanced Japanese.title: JAPN 105 - 01 Advanced Japanese

JAPN 6 - 01 Second-Year Japanese.description: Students carry out intermediate-level tasks that involve listening, speaking, reading, and/or writing, and learn how to read and write 100 additional kanji. Emphasis is placed on developing the student's cultural knowledge relevant to inter-cultural communication.
JAPN 6 - 01 Second-Year Japanese.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or by consent of instructor.
JAPN 6 - 01 Second-Year Japanese.title: JAPN 6 - 01 Second-Year Japanese

JAPN 6 - 02 Second-Year Japanese.description: Students carry out intermediate-level tasks that involve listening, speaking, reading, and/or writing, and learn how to read and write 100 additional kanji. Emphasis is placed on developing the student's cultural knowledge relevant to inter-cultural communication.
JAPN 6 - 02 Second-Year Japanese.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or by consent of instructor.
JAPN 6 - 02 Second-Year Japanese.title: JAPN 6 - 02 Second-Year Japanese

KRSG 100 - 01 University Learning with I.description: Students learn practical ways of maximizing the resources of a public education and research institution. Students collaborate across disciplines, broaden impacts of higher learning, and develop strategies for effective interaction with faculty and the broader professional communities to which they aspire.
KRSG 100 - 01 University Learning with I.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to sophomore, junior, and seniors.
KRSG 100 - 01 University Learning with I.title: KRSG 100 - 01 University Learning with Intention and Purpose

KRSG 12C - 01 Service Learning: Introduc.description: A fast-paced and academically rigorous exercise in four main sections. First and foremost, participants must locate and support a community-service site for three hours each week.  Each student's service commitment requires the student to attend class regularly and share community-service experience with classmates. Students are introduced to the basic requirements of a variety of national service agencies including AmeriCorp, the Peace Corp, City Year, Teach for America, and City Service. Students are required to do community-service work with a member of one of these agencies locally for four hours during the quarter. The last major section of this course teaches students the basics of grant writing and research.
KRSG 12C - 01 Service Learning: Introduc.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to college members.
KRSG 12C - 01 Service Learning: Introduc.title: KRSG 12C - 01 Service Learning: Introduction to National Service/Introduction to Grant Writing

KRSG 2 - 01 Power and Representation in.description: Students explore the radical restructuring of media representation and its consequences over the last three decades. Examines a range of social issues--representation of women and minorities, police brutality, "fake news" and social media--through lenses of specific media spaces, in order to discover the impact of new media, new media environments, and a dynamic media culture on power and representation in American life.
KRSG 2 - 01 Power and Representation in.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1. Enrollment is restricted to Kresge College members.
KRSG 2 - 01 Power and Representation in.title: KRSG 2 - 01 Power and Representation in Media

KRSG 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.description: Defines consensus in terms of inclusive decision-making and explores depth-psychology approaches to facilitating social agreement in culturally diverse settings. Readings include Totem and Taboo, Diversity Calling, and selected articles related to issues of cultural literacy. Recommended for, but not limited to, social science majors.
KRSG 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to Kresge College and Oakes College affiliates or by permission of the instructor.
KRSG 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.title: KRSG 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Diverse Communities

KRSG 68 - 01 Transformative Communicatio.description: Based on Nonviolent Communication (NVC), this experiential course offers skills in intra- and inter-personal conflict transformation by aligning with core values; understanding what motivates self and others; cultivating compassion, even under difficult circumstances; and bringing greater peace into our world.
KRSG 68 - 01 Transformative Communicatio.title: KRSG 68 - 01 Transformative Communication

KRSG 74 - 01 Collaborative Learning: Per.description: Collaborative learning in service of fostering community resilience in response to environmental and social crisis. Students engage with ongoing sustainability and justice projects and develop advanced skills in leadership, personal productivity, project management, communications, and facilitation.
KRSG 74 - 01 Collaborative Learning: Per.title: KRSG 74 - 01 Collaborative Learning: Permaculture Skills

LALS 124 - 01 Brazilian Cinema.description: Surveys films by and/or about women from Brazil, drawing  a picture of contemporary Brazilian cinema through the angle of gender in its articulation with sexuality, race, class, ethnicity, national identity, and other key concepts, while offering a visual and critical introduction to Brazilian culture.
LALS 124 - 01 Brazilian Cinema.title: LALS 124 - 01 Brazilian Cinema

LALS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S.description: Explores the history and practice of Latino media in the U.S. with an emphasis on work created by, for, with, and about Latino constituencies. Course highlights the role that media plays in struggles for social change, political enfranchisement, creative self-expression, and cultural development. Course content varies with instructor.
LALS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S.title: LALS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S

LALS 161P - 01 Theater in the \"Chicano.description: Covers the rise of Teatro Chicano as a cultural-political force within the 1960's "Chicano Power" Movement starting with founding playwriter Luis Valdez and El Teatro Campesino and covering Chicana/o playwrights inspired by the movement, e.g. Cherrie Moraga, Luis Alfaro, and Josefina Lopez.
LALS 161P - 01 Theater in the \"Chicano.title: LALS 161P - 01 Theater in the "Chicano Power" Movement

LALS 170 - 01 Indigenous Struggles in th.description: Focuses on the way Natives of First Peoples have interacted voluntarily and involuntarily with nonindigenous cultures. Examines their perspectives, thoughts, frustrations, and successes. Touches on land issues and examines the way current indigenous cultures of Latin America face and adapt to social change. Focuses mainly on the Andes, lowland Amazon, Mesoamerica, and other areas.
LALS 170 - 01 Indigenous Struggles in th.title: LALS 170 - 01 Indigenous Struggles in the Americas

LALS 178 - 01 Gender, Transnationalism,.description: Focuses on the impact of globalization and transnationalism on gender relations in the Americas. Examines gender and power in the context of neoliberalism, modernity, the nation, social movements, and activism. Explores local and transnational constructions of gender, and the intersection of gender with race, ethnicity, class, and sexuality.
LALS 178 - 01 Gender, Transnationalism,.title: LALS 178 - 01 Gender, Transnationalism, and Globalization

LALS 5 - 01 Introduction to Human Rights.description: Introduces human rights as a way to study social justice. Students gain an understanding of interdisciplinary approaches to human rights as a theory, legally, and as a basis for global social movements.
LALS 5 - 01 Introduction to Human Rights.title: LALS 5 - 01 Introduction to Human Rights and Social Justice

LGST 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.description: Interrogates the presuppositions of punishment as legitimate state power. Decentering crime as punishment's conceptual predicate, wider analysis of the penal state's social-scientific, jurisprudential, and philosophical foundations force us to ask: What is punishment? Why punish? How, and whom, to punish?
LGST 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to legal studies majors during first and second pass enrollment.
LGST 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.title: LGST 182 - 01 The Power to Punish

LING 101 - 01 Phonology I.description: Introduction to how sounds pattern in grammars-why they vary, how they combine, etc. Emphasis is on developing theories to explain the patterns. Topics include distinctive feature theory, phonemic analysis, autosegmental phonology, and principles of syllabification and stress.
LING 101 - 01 Phonology I.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements, course 50.
LING 101 - 01 Phonology I.title: LING 101 - 01 Phonology I

LING 111 - 01 Syntactic Structures.description: Provides a basic introduction to the methods and results of generative grammar. It simultaneously provides an overview of the major syntactic constructions of English.
LING 111 - 01 Syntactic Structures.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
LING 111 - 01 Syntactic Structures.title: LING 111 - 01 Syntactic Structures

LING 50 - 01 Introduction to Linguistics.description: An introduction to the major areas, problems, and techniques of modern linguistics.
LING 50 - 01 Introduction to Linguistics.title: LING 50 - 01 Introduction to Linguistics

LING 80K - 01 Invented Languages, from E.description: Considers invented languages, including Elvish and Klingon, as well as lesser-known ones that tackle ethical, social, or cognitive concerns. Students learn tools from contemporary linguistics to analyze language structures and understand how they relate to creator intentions.
LING 80K - 01 Invented Languages, from E.title: LING 80K - 01 Invented Languages, from Elvish to Esperanto

LIT 1 - 01 Literary Interpretation.description: Close reading and analysis of literary texts, including representative examples of several different genres and periods. An introduction to practical criticism required of all literature majors; should be completed prior to upper-division work in literature.
LIT 1 - 01 Literary Interpretation.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students and sophomores, or literature and proposed literature majors and literature minors.
LIT 1 - 01 Literary Interpretation.title: LIT 1 - 01 Literary Interpretation

LIT 111D - 01 William Shakespeare.description: Study of representative works by William Shakespeare. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Canons, Media. Distribution requirements: Poetry, Pre-1750. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 111D - 01 William Shakespeare.title: LIT 111D - 01 William Shakespeare

LIT 125B - 01 Studies in the English Nov.description: From the 18th to the 20th century. The course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Genres, Geographies. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 125B - 01 Studies in the English Nov.title: LIT 125B - 01 Studies in the English Novel

LIT 133H - 01 Haunted by the Forgotten W.description: The Korean War has the dubious distinction of being known as "the Forgotten War" in a U.S. context. Course examines novels, short stories, film, popular visual narratives, and historical accounts of the Korean War and its often-circuitous legacies.
LIT 133H - 01 Haunted by the Forgotten W.title: LIT 133H - 01 Haunted by the Forgotten War: Literature and Film of the Korean War

LIT 137A - 01 Global Cities.description: Examines cities as social spaces and as local spaces in the global economy and global imaginary. Focus is interdisciplinary, including literature, film, cultural studies, history, and sociology. Topic changes; please see the Class Search for current topic. Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories Distribution requirement: Global. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 137A - 01 Global Cities.title: LIT 137A - 01 Global Cities

LIT 141C - 01 Classical Chinese Culture.description: Survey of writing and culture from the Tang through early Ming dynasties (sixth century C.E. through 16th century C.E.). Themes include literary, religious, and philosophical innovation; courtly life; cultural contacts with non-Chinese people; and transformations of state and society.  Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories. Distribution requirements: Global, Poetry,  Pre-1750.
LIT 141C - 01 Classical Chinese Culture.title: LIT 141C - 01 Classical Chinese Culture and Literature, Sixth Century through 16th Century

LIT 146G - 01 Queer(y)ing Victorian Lite.description: Examines mid- to late-19th-century English representations of non-normative gender and sexuality in popular culture. Considers how these figures in fiction conform to or resist established perceptions of gender, sexuality, race, and empire. Critical approach designations: Histories, Power and Subjectivities.
LIT 146G - 01 Queer(y)ing Victorian Lite.title: LIT 146G - 01 Queer(y)ing Victorian Literature

LIT 149C - 01 The 1960s.description: An interdisciplinary study of the cultural and social movements of the 1960s. Critical approach designations: Histories, Power and Subjectivities. Distribution requirement: Global.
LIT 149C - 01 The 1960s.title: LIT 149C - 01 The 1960s

LIT 164J - 01 Jewish Writers and the Ame.description: An examination of some major Jewish writers and their responses to the American city. Major writers: Henry Roth, Saul Bellow, Bernard Malamud, J. Kaplan, Philip Roth. A look at Yiddish and other minority writers, and including sociological and historical materials on the American city. The course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Histories, Power and Subjectivities. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 164J - 01 Jewish Writers and the Ame.title: LIT 164J - 01 Jewish Writers and the American City

LIT 179A - 01 Advanced Writing: Fiction.description: Intensive work in writing fiction. Critical approach designation: Genres. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 179A - 01 Advanced Writing: Fiction.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to creative writing literature majors.
LIT 179A - 01 Advanced Writing: Fiction.title: LIT 179A - 01 Advanced Writing: Fiction

LIT 179C - 01 Methods and Materials.description: Focuses on a particular process or subject used in the production of a literary text. Course is intended to work as a bridge between invention and scholarship. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for current topic. Critical approach designation: Genres. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 179C - 01 Methods and Materials.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to creative writing literature majors.
LIT 179C - 01 Methods and Materials.title: LIT 179C - 01 Methods and Materials

LIT 186A - 01 Introduction to Latin Lite.description: Reading proficiency in Latin required. Course topic changes; see Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Canons, Histories. Distribution requirement: Pre-1750. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 186A - 01 Introduction to Latin Lite.title: LIT 186A - 01 Introduction to Latin Literature

LIT 189B - 01 El Siglo XIX en America La.description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficiency in Spanish required. Follows the literary manifestations of the growing consciousness of the Latin American writer: discovery of native themes, comparative analysis of Spanish American and Peninsular European models, search for a "new language" literally and figuratively. Relates historical events with literary movements. Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories. Distribution requirement: Global.
LIT 189B - 01 El Siglo XIX en America La.title: LIT 189B - 01 El Siglo XIX en America Latina: cultura, política y sociedad

LIT 189Z - 01 Literatura de Chile.description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficienty in Spanish required. Focusing on narrative and poetry in Chile and their transformations during the 20th century, course examines the relationships between literature, nation, and representation. Critical approach designations: Canons, Histories. Distribution requirement: Global.
LIT 189Z - 01 Literatura de Chile.title: LIT 189Z - 01 Literatura de Chile

LIT 190X - 01 Temas de la literatura y c.description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficiency in Spanish is required. Examines authors or issues in Spanish and Latin American literature and cultures. Course topic changes; see the Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories. Distribution requirement: Senior Seminar. Spanish studies majors may use this course to satisfy the Spanish studies senior exit requirement. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 190X - 01 Temas de la literatura y c.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): LIT 101.  Enrollment is restricted to senior literature majors.
LIT 190X - 01 Temas de la literatura y c.title: LIT 190X - 01 Temas de la literatura y cultura espanolas y latinoamericanas

LIT 80I - 01 Topics in American Culture.description: A history of one or more cultural genres in written, visual, and/or musical forms. Course topic changes; please see the Class Search for the current topic. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 80I - 01 Topics in American Culture.title: LIT 80I - 01 Topics in American Culture

LIT 80Q - 01 Jane the Virgin: Latinx Rea.description: What does a telenovela spoof about a virgin Latinx mother and aspiring romance novelist have to do with literature? Course explores Jane the Virgin as a commentary on the tastes, identities, and politics of 21st-century Latinx readers and writers.
LIT 80Q - 01 Jane the Virgin: Latinx Rea.title: LIT 80Q - 01 Jane the Virgin: Latinx Readers and (Latin) American Literature

LIT 90 - 01 Introduction to Creative Wri.description: Introduction to the crafts and techniques of poetry, fiction, and creative non-fiction, identifying and exploring traditional and non-traditional literary forms and genres while working on individual creative writing projects. An author reading and two workshop sections per week. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 90 - 01 Introduction to Creative Wri.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing requirement. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students, sophomores, and juniors.
LIT 90 - 01 Introduction to Creative Wri.title: LIT 90 - 01 Introduction to Creative Writing

LIT 90 - 02 Introduction to Creative Wri.description: Introduction to the crafts and techniques of poetry, fiction, and creative non-fiction, identifying and exploring traditional and non-traditional literary forms and genres while working on individual creative writing projects. An author reading and two workshop sections per week. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 90 - 02 Introduction to Creative Wri.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing requirement. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students, sophomores, and juniors.
LIT 90 - 02 Introduction to Creative Wri.title: LIT 90 - 02 Introduction to Creative Writing

LIT 90 - 03 Introduction to Creative Wri.description: Introduction to the crafts and techniques of poetry, fiction, and creative non-fiction, identifying and exploring traditional and non-traditional literary forms and genres while working on individual creative writing projects. An author reading and two workshop sections per week. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 90 - 03 Introduction to Creative Wri.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite: satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing requirement. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students, sophomores, and juniors.
LIT 90 - 03 Introduction to Creative Wri.title: LIT 90 - 03 Introduction to Creative Writing

LIT 91A - 01 Intermediate Fiction Writin.description: An intermediate-level course in fiction designed for prospective applicants to the creative writing concentration. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 91A - 01 Intermediate Fiction Writin.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 90, or Creative Writing 10. Enrollment is restricted to first-year, sophomore, and junior students.
LIT 91A - 01 Intermediate Fiction Writin.title: LIT 91A - 01 Intermediate Fiction Writing

LIT 91B - 01 Intermediate Poetry Writing.description: An intermediate-level course in poetry designed for prospective applicants to the creative writing concentration. May be repeated for credit.
LIT 91B - 01 Intermediate Poetry Writing.title: LIT 91B - 01 Intermediate Poetry Writing

MATH 100 - 01 Introduction to Proof and.description: Students learn the basic concepts and ideas necessary for upper-division mathematics and techniques of mathematical proof. Introduction to sets, relations, elementary mathematical logic, proof by contradiction, mathematical induction, and counting arguments.
MATH 100 - 01 Introduction to Proof and.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements; course 11A or 19A or 20A; and course 21 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 10 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics  10A.
MATH 100 - 01 Introduction to Proof and.title: MATH 100 - 01 Introduction to Proof and Problem Solving

MATH 11A - 01 Calculus with Applications.description: A modern course stressing conceptual understanding, relevance, and problem solving. The derivative of polynomial, exponential, and trigonometric functions of a single variable is developed and applied to a wide range of problems involving graphing, approximation, and optimization. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and course 19A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A and 15A, or Economics 11A.
MATH 11A - 01 Calculus with Applications.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 3 or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3; or mathematics placement (MP) score of 300 or higher; or AP Calculus AB exam score of 3 or higher.
MATH 11A - 01 Calculus with Applications.title: MATH 11A - 01 Calculus with Applications

MATH 11B - 01 Calculus with Applications.description: Starting with the fundamental theorem of calculus and related techniques, the integral of functions of a single variable is developed and applied to problems in geometry, probability, physics, and differential equations. Polynomial approximations, Taylor series, and their applications conclude the course. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 19B, or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11B and 15B, or Economics 11B.
MATH 11B - 01 Calculus with Applications.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 11A or 19A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15A or AP Calculus AB exam score of 4 or 5, or BC exam score of 3 or higher, or IB Mathematics Higher Level exam score of 5 or higher.
MATH 11B - 01 Calculus with Applications.title: MATH 11B - 01 Calculus with Applications

MATH 19A - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.description: The limit of a function, calculating limits, continuity, tangents, velocities, and other instantaneous rates of change. Derivatives, the chain rule, implicit differentiation, higher derivatives. Exponential functions, inverse functions, and their derivatives. The mean value theorem, monotonic functions, concavity, and points of inflection. Applied maximum and minimum problems. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and course 11A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A and 15A,or Economics 11A.
MATH 19A - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 3; or mathematics placement (MP) score of 400 or higher; or AP Calculus AB exam score of 3 or higher.
MATH 19A - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.title: MATH 19A - 01 Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics

MATH 19B - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.description: The definite integral and the fundamental theorem of calculus. Areas, volumes. Integration by parts, trigonometric substitution, and partial fractions methods. Improper integrals. Sequences, series, absolute convergence and convergence tests. Power series, Taylor and Maclaurin series. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and course 11B, Applied Math and Statistics 11B and 15B, or Economics 11B.
MATH 19B - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 19A or 20A or AP Calculus AB exam score of 4 or 5, or BC exam score of 3 or higher, or IB Mathematics Higher Level exam score of 5 of higher.
MATH 19B - 01 Calculus for Science, Engi.title: MATH 19B - 01 Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics

MATH 21 - 01 Linear Algebra.description: Systems of linear equations matrices, determinants. Introduces abstract vector spaces, linear transformation, inner products, the geometry of Euclidean space, and eigenvalues. Students cannot receive credit for this course and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 10 or 10A.
MATH 21 - 01 Linear Algebra.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 11A or 19A or 20A  or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 11A or 15A.
MATH 21 - 01 Linear Algebra.title: MATH 21 - 01 Linear Algebra

MATH 23A - 01 Vector Calculus.description: Vectors in n-dimensional Euclidean space. The inner and cross products. The derivative of functions from n-dimensional to m-dimensional Euclidean space is studied as a linear transformation having matrix representation. Paths in 3-dimensions, arc length, vector differential calculus, Taylor's theorem in several variables, extrema of real-valued functions, constrained extrema and Lagrange multipliers, the implicit function theorem, some applications. Students cannot receive credit for this course and course 22. (Formerly Multivariable Calculus.)
MATH 23A - 01 Vector Calculus.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 19B or 20B or AP calculus BC exam score of 4 or 5.
MATH 23A - 01 Vector Calculus.title: MATH 23A - 01 Vector Calculus

MATH 23B - 01 Vector Calculus.description: Double integral, changing the order of integration. Triple integrals, maps of the plane, change of variables theorem, improper double integrals. Path integrals, line integrals, parametrized surfaces, area of a surface, surface integrals. Green's theorem, Stokes' theorem, conservative fields, Gauss' theorem. Applications to physics and differential equations, differential forms. (Formerly Multivariable Calculus.)
MATH 23B - 01 Vector Calculus.title: MATH 23B - 01 Vector Calculus

MATH 3 - 01 Precalculus.description: Inverse functions and graphs; exponential and logarithmic functions, their graphs, and use in mathematical models of the real world; rates of change; trigonometry, trigonometric functions, and their graphs; and geometric series. Students cannot receive credit for both course 3 and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3. Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3 can substitute for course 3.
MATH 3 - 01 Precalculus.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 2 or mathematics placement (MP) score of 200 or higher.
MATH 3 - 01 Precalculus.title: MATH 3 - 01 Precalculus

MERR 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Chang.description: Students in this course explore and discuss the applicability of the Social Change Model of Leadership Development (Wagner, 1996) within the immediate UCSC, Crown College, and Merrill College communities. Students draw connections between concepts of leadership, community development, and community service. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. Students must have a leadership role (e.g., R.A., student government) with Crown College or Merrill College.
MERR 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Chang.title: MERR 38 - 01 Leadership for Social Change

MERR 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Chang.description: Students in this course explore and discuss the applicability of the Social Change Model of Leadership Development (Wagner, 1996) within the immediate UCSC, Crown College, and Merrill College communities. Students draw connections between concepts of leadership, community development, and community service. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. Students must have a leadership role (e.g., R.A., student government) with Crown College or Merrill College.
MERR 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Chang.title: MERR 38 - 02 Leadership for Social Change

MERR 85B - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.description: Supervised hands-on experience assisting in local K-12 school classrooms. Students attend UCSC class meetings, complete relevant readings in educational theory, and present a final assignment. This course requires more hours than course 85C and involves travel to Pescadero twice per week. May be repeated for credit.
MERR 85B - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.enrollment_requirements: Priority enrollment restricted to Merrill College members.
MERR 85B - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.title: MERR 85B - 01 Merrill Classroom Connection Field Study

MERR 85C - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.description:
Supervised hands-on experience assisting in local K-12 school classrooms. Students also attend UCSC course meetings, complete relevant readings in educational theory, and present a final assignment. Please see 
http://merrill.ucsc.edu/academics/programs-and-courses/classroom-connection/index.html for conditions that must be met prior to placement at local schools. May be repeated for credit.
MERR 85C - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.enrollment_requirements: Priority enrollment is restricted to Merrill College members.
MERR 85C - 01 Merrill Classroom Connecti.title: MERR 85C - 01 Merrill Classroom Connection Field Study

MERR 90F - 01 Merrill Field Study Practi.description: Offers Merrill students an opportunity for practical field study experience with preparation and support for practical skill development and critical reflection on service-learning experience.
MERR 90F - 01 Merrill Field Study Practi.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to sophomore, junior, and senior college members.
MERR 90F - 01 Merrill Field Study Practi.title: MERR 90F - 01 Merrill Field Study Practicum

METX 119L - 01 Microbiology Laboratory.description: An introduction to the principles and practices of laboratory microbiology, with a substantial presentation of optical microscopy. Students are billed a materials fee.
METX 119L - 01 Microbiology Laboratory.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): previous or concurrent enrollment in 119 and either BIOL 20L, BIOL 101L, or BIOL 102L. Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements. Non-majors enroll by permission of the instructor.
METX 119L - 01 Microbiology Laboratory.title: METX 119L - 01 Microbiology Laboratory

MUSC 12 - 01 Mariachi Ensemble.description: Focuses on the stylistic practice of mariachi music of Mexico. Centralizes efforts learning dance music as the son jalisciense, as well as popular singing genres that include the huapango, canción ranchera, corridos, and boleros. Students must have previous experience with music performance and applicable instruments. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 12 - 01 Mariachi Ensemble.title: MUSC 12 - 01 Mariachi Ensemble

MUSC 12B - 01 Mexican Folklorico Music a.description: Instruction in the aesthetic, cultural, and historical dimensions of Mexican Folklorico dance and music. Brings together a dance ensemble and a music ensemble. Enrollment is by permission of the instructor. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 12B - 01 Mexican Folklorico Music a.title: MUSC 12B - 01 Mexican Folklorico Music and Dance

MUSC 150X - 01 Theoretical Practices of.description: Examines theoretical practices and compositional methods of 20th-Century American composers including Charles Ives, Henry Cowell, Ruth Crawford, Johanna Beyer, Harry Partch, Conlon Nancarrow, John Cage, James Tenney, Kenneth Gaburo, George Russell, and Ornette Coleman.
MUSC 150X - 01 Theoretical Practices of.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 30A, 30B, and 30C.  Enrollment is restricted to music majors.
MUSC 150X - 01 Theoretical Practices of.title: MUSC 150X - 01 Theoretical Practices of American Music

MUSC 166 - 01 Chamber Singers.description: The study of selected works for small vocal ensemble from the 15th through 20th centuries, with performances on and off campus throughout the academic year. Students must have demonstrated vocal and music reading skills. Admission by audition with instructor prior to first class meeting. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 166 - 01 Chamber Singers.title: MUSC 166 - 01 Chamber Singers

MUSC 1C - 01 University Concert Choir.description: A study of selected works for mixed chorus, with emphasis on masterworks for chorus and orchestra, culminating in one or more public concerts. Familiarity with basic music notation recommended. Admission by audition with conductor prior to first class meeting. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 1C - 01 University Concert Choir.title: MUSC 1C - 01 University Concert Choir

MUSC 2 - 01 University Orchestra.description: A study of selected works for orchestra, culminating in one or more public concerts. Admission by audition with conductor prior to first class meeting. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 2 - 01 University Orchestra.title: MUSC 2 - 01 University Orchestra

MUSC 3 - 01 Large Jazz Ensemble.description: Instruction in performance in large jazz ensembles with written arrangements. Prepares a specific repertory for public performance. Admission by audition with conductor prior to first class meeting. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 3 - 01 Large Jazz Ensemble.title: MUSC 3 - 01 Large Jazz Ensemble

MUSC 5A - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.description: Instruction in practice and performance of gamelan music from Java or Sunda. Preparation of several works for public presentation. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 5A - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.title: MUSC 5A - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensemble: Beginning

MUSC 5A - 02 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.description: Instruction in practice and performance of gamelan music from Java or Sunda. Preparation of several works for public presentation. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 5A - 02 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.title: MUSC 5A - 02 West Javanese Gamelan Ensemble: Beginning

MUSC 5A - 03 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.description: Instruction in practice and performance of gamelan music from Java or Sunda. Preparation of several works for public presentation. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 5A - 03 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.title: MUSC 5A - 03 West Javanese Gamelan Ensemble: Beginning

MUSC 5B - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.description: Instruction in practice and performance of gamelan music from Java or Sunda. Preparation of several works for public presentation. Attend first class meeting. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 5B - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.title: MUSC 5B - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensemble: Intermediate

MUSC 5C - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.description: Instruction in practice and performance of gamelan music from Java or Sunda. Preparation of several works for public presentation. Attend first class meeting. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 5C - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensem.title: MUSC 5C - 01 West Javanese Gamelan Ensemble: Advanced

MUSC 80K - 01 Sound in Art, Science, and.description: Study the role of sound in artistic creation and scientific research related to the environment. Topics include: environmental sound monitoring, increasing environmental awareness, social activism, discovery of sound phenomena, knowledge of audio tools and techniques, sound and environmental problem-solving.
MUSC 80K - 01 Sound in Art, Science, and.title: MUSC 80K - 01 Sound in Art, Science, and the Environment

MUSC 80V - 01 The Music of the Beatles.description: The most significant group in the history of popular music, the Beatles spanned the gamut of styles from hard-edged R & B to sophisticated art-rock. This course explores their work in detail, in its own terms, and in the historical/cultural/technological contexts. Students cannot receive credit for both this course and course 180V in the same quarter. Course 11C is recommended but not required as preparation.
MUSC 80V - 01 The Music of the Beatles.title: MUSC 80V - 01 The Music of the Beatles

MUSC 80X - 01 Music of India.description: A survey course in Hindustani (North Indian) and Karnatak (South Indian) music covering the Raga (modal system) and Tala (metric system) as they have developed in the two traditions. Consideration is given to the historical development of the music, from Vedic chanting to the modern Raga system; social functions of the music throughout history; and instrumental and vocal forms with an emphasis on listening.
MUSC 80X - 01 Music of India.title: MUSC 80X - 01 Music of India

MUSC 8A - 01 Beginning Balinese Gamelan.description: Instruction in Balinese gamelan. Utilizes pitched percussion instruments to learn highly ornate and complex pieces through rote learning; students are not required to read music. Focuses on traditional repertoire and basic gamelan techniques for public performance. Enrollment by permission of the instructor at the first class meeting.  (Formerly Balinese Gamelan Ensemble.) May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 8A - 01 Beginning Balinese Gamelan.title: MUSC 8A - 01 Beginning Balinese Gamelan

MUSC 8B - 01 Advanced Balinese Gamelan.description: Instruction in Balinese gamelan. Utilizes pitched percussion instruments to learn highly ornate and complex pieces through rote learning; students are not required to read music. Focuses on advanced traditional and contemporary repertoire for public performance. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 8B - 01 Advanced Balinese Gamelan.title: MUSC 8B - 01 Advanced Balinese Gamelan

MUSC 9 - 01 Wind Ensemble.description: A study of selected advanced-level works for wind ensemble, culminating in one or more public concerts. Admission by audition with conductor prior to first class meeting. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
MUSC 9 - 01 Wind Ensemble.title: MUSC 9 - 01 Wind Ensemble

OAKS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S.description: Explores the history and practice of Latino media in the U.S. with an emphasis on work created by, for, with, and about Latino constituencies. Course highlights the role that media plays in struggles for social change, political enfranchisement, creative self-expression, and cultural development. Course content varies with instructor.
OAKS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S.title: OAKS 128 - 01 Latino Media in the U.S

OAKS 151B - 01 Community Literacies Fiel.description: Field study for Corre la Voz interns. Intensive on-site training and participation in team teaching of dual-language  (Spanish English) students (4th-5th grade). Literacies include social-emotional, expressive (artistic/dramatic), collaborative problem-solving, academic, and use of digital tools as well as traditional tools. Enrollment by interview only, and successful application to the Corre la Voz program. Concurrent enrollment in course 151A is required during the first quarter after which course 151B may be repeated by itself. May be repeated for credit.
OAKS 151B - 01 Community Literacies Fiel.title: OAKS 151B - 01 Community Literacies Field Study

OAKS 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.description: Defines consensus in terms of inclusive decision-making and explores depth-psychology approaches to facilitating social agreement in culturally diverse settings. Readings include Totem and Taboo, Diversity Calling, and selected articles related to issues of cultural literacy. Recommended for, but not limited to, social science majors.
OAKS 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to Oakes College and Kresge College affiliates or by permission of the instructor.
OAKS 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Dive.title: OAKS 45 - 01 Achieving Consensus in Diverse Communities

OAKS 48 - 01 Slugs Speak: Our Stories, O.description: Students learn about the power of story to make change through this Storytelling for Justice project. Students practice developing personal life stories, learn to create and facilitate community space, and participate in a community storytelling event focused on intersectional identities.
OAKS 48 - 01 Slugs Speak: Our Stories, O.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to Oakes College affiliates or by instructor permission.
OAKS 48 - 01 Slugs Speak: Our Stories, O.title: OAKS 48 - 01 Slugs Speak: Our Stories, Our Selves

OCEA 1 - 01 The Oceans.description: An interdisciplinary introduction to oceanography focusing on biological, chemical, geological, and physical processes. Covers topics such as origins and structure of planet Earth and its oceans, co-evolution of Earth and life, plate tectonics, liquid water and the hydrologic and hydrothermal cycles, salinity and elemental cycles, ocean circulation, primary production and nutrient cycles, plankton and nekton, life on the sea floor, near shore and estuarine communities, future environmental problems our oceans face. Students may also enroll in and receive credit for Earth Sciences 1.
OCEA 1 - 01 The Oceans.title: OCEA 1 - 01 The Oceans

OCEA 80B - 01 Our Changing Planet.description: Interdisciplinary scientific perspective on Earth system, focusing on human impacts on global environment. Introduces concepts of Earth system science and explores topics such as global warming, ozone depletion, pollution, deforestation, and future climate change. Prerequisite(s): high school chemistry course recommended.
OCEA 80B - 01 Our Changing Planet.title: OCEA 80B - 01 Our Changing Planet

PHIL 11 - 01 Introduction to Philosophy.description: An introduction to the main areas of philosophy through critical reflection on and analysis of both classical and contemporary texts. Focuses on central and enduring problems in philosophy such as skepticism about the external world, the mind-body problem, and the nature of morality.
PHIL 11 - 01 Introduction to Philosophy.title: PHIL 11 - 01 Introduction to Philosophy

PHIL 27 - 01 Business Ethics.description: Examination of the ethical issues that arise in connection with a variety of specific business contexts. Common topics include: advertising, environmental harm, employee-employer relationships, finance, capitalism, market failure, government regulation, work-life balance, and consumer rights.
PHIL 27 - 01 Business Ethics.title: PHIL 27 - 01 Business Ethics

PHYS 180 - 01 Biophysics.description: Physical principles and techniques used in biology: X-ray diffraction; nuclear magnetic resonance; statistics, kinetics, and thermodynamics of macromolecules; viscosity and diffusion; DNA/RNA pairing; electrophoresis; physics of enzymes; biological energy conversion; optical tweezers.
PHYS 180 - 01 Biophysics.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 112; students who have a biochemistry background may contact instructor for permission. Restricted to juniors and seniors.
PHYS 180 - 01 Biophysics.title: PHYS 180 - 01 Biophysics

PHYS 5B - 01 Introduction to Physics II.description: A continuation of 5A. Wave motion in matter, including sound waves. Geometrical optics, interference and polarization, statics and dynamics of fluids.
PHYS 5B - 01 Introduction to Physics II.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 5A/L and Mathematics 19A or 20A; concurrent enrollment in course 5M is required. Corequisite: Mathematics 19B or 20B.
PHYS 5B - 01 Introduction to Physics II.title: PHYS 5B - 01 Introduction to Physics II

PHYS 5C - 01 Introduction to Physics III.description: Introduction to electricity and magnetism. Electromagnetic radiation, Maxwell's equations.
PHYS 5C - 01 Introduction to Physics III.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 5A/L and Mathematics 19B or 20B. Concurrent enrollment in course 5N is required.
PHYS 5C - 01 Introduction to Physics III.title: PHYS 5C - 01 Introduction to Physics III

PHYS 6A - 01 Introductory Physics I.description: Elementary mechanics. Vectors, Newton's laws, inverse square force laws, work and energy, conservation of momentum and energy, and oscillations.
PHYS 6A - 01 Introductory Physics I.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics 11A or 19A or 20A or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15A. Concurrent enrollment in course 6L required.
PHYS 6A - 01 Introductory Physics I.title: PHYS 6A - 01 Introductory Physics I

PHYS 6B - 01 Introductory Physics II.description: A continuation of 6A. Geometric optics; statics and dynamics of fluids; introduction to thermodynamics, including temperature, heat, thermal conductivity, and molecular motion; wave motion in matter, including sound waves.
PHYS 6B - 01 Introductory Physics II.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5A/L or 6A/L; and Mathematics 11B or 19B or 20B or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15B.
PHYS 6B - 01 Introductory Physics II.title: PHYS 6B - 01 Introductory Physics II

PHYS 6C - 01 Introductory Physics III.description: Introduction to electricity and magnetism. Elementary circuits; Maxwell's equations; electromagnetic radiation; interference and polarization of light.
PHYS 6C - 01 Introductory Physics III.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 5A/L or 6A/L, and Mathematics 11B or 19B or 20B or Applied Mathematics and Statistics 15B.
PHYS 6C - 01 Introductory Physics III.title: PHYS 6C - 01 Introductory Physics III

PHYS 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in.description: Introduction to research for first-year students interested in physics and astrophysics. Students complete projects in small groups with scientists. Introduces techniques for collaboration; science writing; physics careers. Continuing course spanning two quarters. Prerequisite(s): course 9A. Enrollment is restricted to first-year proposed applied physics, physics, and physics (astrophysics) majors and by permission of the instructor.
PHYS 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in.title: PHYS 9B - 01 Introduction to Research in Physics and Astrophysics

PHYS 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in.description: Introduction to research for first-year students interested in physics and astrophysics. Students complete projects in small groups with scientists. Introduces techniques for collaboration; science writing; physics careers. Continuing course spanning two quarters. Prerequisite(s): course 9A. Enrollment is restricted to first-year proposed applied physics, physics, and physics (astrophysics) majors and by permission of the instructor.
PHYS 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in.title: PHYS 9B - 02 Introduction to Research in Physics and Astrophysics

POLI 140D - 01 Politics of East Asia.description: Explores the political development of East Asia's primary democracies: Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan. Examines the historical origins of these states, the process through which they emerged from authoritarian roots, and topics such as protest, corruption, and women's political roles.
POLI 140D - 01 Politics of East Asia.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing and Composition requirements.
POLI 140D - 01 Politics of East Asia.title: POLI 140D - 01 Politics of East Asia

POLI 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.description: Interrogates the presuppositions of punishment as legitimate state power. Decentering crime as punishment's conceptual predicate, wider analysis of the penal state's social-scientific, jurisprudential, and philosophical foundations force us to ask: What is punishment? Why punish? How, and whom, to punish?
POLI 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to politics majors during first and second pass enrollment.
POLI 182 - 01 The Power to Punish.title: POLI 182 - 01 The Power to Punish

POLI 61 - 01 Politics of Social Policy.description: Introduces social policy around the world. Some countries provide free and good-quality health and education, as well as a minimum income to all citizens. Others, instead, provide meager benefits to few citizens.
POLI 61 - 01 Politics of Social Policy.title: POLI 61 - 01 Politics of Social Policy

PORT 65A - 01 Accelerated Intermediate P.description: A systematic grammar review is combined with literacy and cultural readings, while communicative exercises focus on improving students' ability to understand and hold sustained conversations. Students expand their vocabulary and knowledge of Brazil and other Portuguese-speaking  cultures through films, popular music, and other culturally authentic materials.
PORT 65A - 01 Accelerated Intermediate P.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1B or 60B, or by consent of instructor.
PORT 65A - 01 Accelerated Intermediate P.title: PORT 65A - 01 Accelerated Intermediate Portuguese

PORT 80 - 01 Voices from the Portuguese-.description: Examines key literary texts and films of the Portuguese-speaking world (Brazil, Portugual, and Africa), and the strategies they use to portray notions of national identity, which were transformed and enriched by transnational contact. Taught in English.
PORT 80 - 01 Voices from the Portuguese-.title: PORT 80 - 01 Voices from the Portuguese-Speaking World: Portugal, Brazil and Africa

PRTR 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.description: Critically interrogates the multiple meanings of "data" and "democracy." Students examine case studies on the mobilization and framing of "democracy" in particular moments. Students also analyze concerns and opportunities provided by "data" management and archival practices of evidence and cataloging.
PRTR 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.title: PRTR 175S - 01 Data and Democracy

PRTR 63W - 01 Ways of Knowing.description: Creativity in different disciplines is developed via different ways of knowing. Musical, visual, scientific, and spatial literacy demand understanding which is not primarily logocentric. Explores how practitioners of arts and science develop their work and conceptualize its execution. (Formerly course 80K.)
PRTR 63W - 01 Ways of Knowing.enrollment_requirements: Enrollment is restricted to college members.
PRTR 63W - 01 Ways of Knowing.title: PRTR 63W - 01 Ways of Knowing

PSYC 1 - 01 Introduction to Psychology.description: Introduces prospective majors to the scientific study of behavior and mental processes and also provides an overview for non-majors. Emphasizes social, cognitive, developmental, and personality psychology and their interrelations.
PSYC 1 - 01 Introduction to Psychology.title: PSYC 1 - 01 Introduction to Psychology

PSYC 2 - 01 Introduction to Psychologica.description: An introduction to elementary statistical principles and techniques relevant to psychological research. Topics covered include basic parametric and nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, and simple factorial designs. This course is prerequisite to course 181.
PSYC 2 - 01 Introduction to Psychologica.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1 or 20, and Applied Mathematics and Statistics 3 or 6 or Mathematics 3 or 4 or 11A or satisfactory placement score on math placement exam or CEEB Advanced Placement Calculus AB exam.
PSYC 2 - 01 Introduction to Psychologica.title: PSYC 2 - 01 Introduction to Psychological Statistics

SOCY 117M - 01 Immigration Enforcement a.description: The intensification of immigration enforcement in the United States and the associated rise of mass deportations have reached the lives of millions of immigrants and local communities. Course covers the context, determinants, and consequences of enforcement and deportation practices.
SOCY 117M - 01 Immigration Enforcement a.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): SOCY 1 or SOCY 10 or SOCY 15 or LALS 1. Enrollment restricted to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
SOCY 117M - 01 Immigration Enforcement a.title: SOCY 117M - 01 Immigration Enforcement and Deportations

SOCY 148 - 01 Educational Inequality.description: Examines educational inequality in the United States, focusing on contemporary debates and issues, especially in the California context. Covers schooling from preschool to higher education, and examines educational inequality from a system, setting, and individual-level perspective. (Formerly Sociology of Learning.)
SOCY 148 - 01 Educational Inequality.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): courses 3A and 3B, or by instructor permission. Enrollment restricted to junior, senior majors, proposed majors, and minors in sociology, education, global information and social enterprise, and Latin American studies/sociology combined.
SOCY 148 - 01 Educational Inequality.title: SOCY 148 - 01 Educational Inequality

SOCY 170P - 01 The Political Economy of.description: Explores the enduring racial and economic legacies of slavery and colonialism in relation to contemporary social problems, with an emphasis on segregation, policing, the prison industrial complex, immigration, and borders.
SOCY 170P - 01 The Political Economy of.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): SOCY 1 or SOCY 10 or SOCY 15 or CRES 10, or by permission of the instructor.
SOCY 170P - 01 The Political Economy of.title: SOCY 170P - 01 The Political Economy of Race

SPAN 156A - 01 The Language of Latin Ame.description: Explores Latin American culture through its cinematic art. Students are exposed to and participate in discussion, analysis, and commentary on important social, historical, and political issues presented in the films. Provides a greater understanding of Latin America, and works toward advanced communicative proficiency and comprehension of linguistic variations in countries such as Cuba, Argentina, México, Bolivia, Chile, and others.
SPAN 156A - 01 The Language of Latin Ame.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Spanish 6 or Spanish for Heritage Speakers 6 or placement into Spanish 156A via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 156A - 01 The Language of Latin Ame.title: SPAN 156A - 01 The Language of Latin America Cinema

SPAN 190A - 01 Temas de la literatura y.description: Speaking, reading, and writing proficiency in Spanish is required. Examines authors or issues in Spanish and Latin American literature and cultures. Course topic changes; see the Class Search for the current topic. Critical approach designations: Geographies, Histories. Distribution requirement: Senior Seminar. Spanish studies majors may use this course to satisfy the Spanish studies senior exit requirement. May be repeated for credit.
SPAN 190A - 01 Temas de la literatura y.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Spanish 114 or Spanish for Heritage Speakers 115.  Enrollment is restricted to senior Spanish studies majors.
SPAN 190A - 01 Temas de la literatura y.title: SPAN 190A - 01 Temas de la literatura y cultura espanolas y latinoamericanas

SPAN 4 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.description: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
SPAN 4 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1B or 3 or placement into Spanish 4 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 4 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 4 - 01 Second-Year Spanish

SPAN 4 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.description: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
SPAN 4 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1B or 3 or placement into Spanish 4 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 4 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 4 - 02 Second-Year Spanish

SPAN 4 - 03 Second-Year Spanish.description: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various sociopolitical and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
SPAN 4 - 03 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 1B or 3 or placement into Spanish 4 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 4 - 03 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 4 - 03 Second-Year Spanish

SPAN 5 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.description: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various socio-political and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
SPAN 5 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 4 or placement into Spanish 5 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 5 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 5 - 01 Second-Year Spanish

SPAN 5 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.description: Includes comprehensive grammar review, composition, readings, and discussion. Reading and audiovisual material deal with various socio-political and cultural issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Classes are conducted in Spanish.
SPAN 5 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 4 or placement into Spanish 5 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 5 - 02 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 5 - 02 Second-Year Spanish

SPAN 5M - 01 Medical Spanish.description: Students learn medical vocabulary, useful expressions, suitable grammatical structures, and cultural background to be able to interact with Spanish-speaking patients and doctors. Medical Spanish fulfills language requirement for the health sciences and human biology majors.
SPAN 5M - 01 Medical Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Spanish 4; or Spanish for Heritage Speakers 4, or 5, or 6; or placement into Spanish 5 via the online Spanish Placement Examination. Enrollment is restricted to health sciences and human biology majors.
SPAN 5M - 01 Medical Spanish.title: SPAN 5M - 01 Medical Spanish

SPAN 6 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.description: Increases oral and written proficiency using authentic reading materials which focus on such topics as social class, ethnicity, education, religion, economic, and political developments in the Spanish-speaking world.
SPAN 6 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): course 5 or 5M or placement into Spanish 6 via the online Spanish Placement Examination.
SPAN 6 - 01 Second-Year Spanish.title: SPAN 6 - 01 Second-Year Spanish

SPHS 6 - 01 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.description: Deals with orthography, lexicon development, morphology, syntax, and other linguistic topics as applied to the development of all language skills (listening, reading, speaking, and writing). Emphasizes reading and writing about well-known and pivotal authentic texts of varying genres and formats from the Spanish-speaking world. Emphasis is on South America.
SPHS 6 - 01 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.title: SPHS 6 - 01 Spanish for Heritage Speakers

SPHS 6 - 02 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.description: Deals with orthography, lexicon development, morphology, syntax, and other linguistic topics as applied to the development of all language skills (listening, reading, speaking, and writing). Emphasizes reading and writing about well-known and pivotal authentic texts of varying genres and formats from the Spanish-speaking world. Emphasis is on South America.
SPHS 6 - 02 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.title: SPHS 6 - 02 Spanish for Heritage Speakers

SPHS 6 - 03 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.description: Deals with orthography, lexicon development, morphology, syntax, and other linguistic topics as applied to the development of all language skills (listening, reading, speaking, and writing). Emphasizes reading and writing about well-known and pivotal authentic texts of varying genres and formats from the Spanish-speaking world. Emphasis is on South America.
SPHS 6 - 03 Spanish for Heritage Speaker.title: SPHS 6 - 03 Spanish for Heritage Speakers

STEV 11C - 01 ELP Core Course: Tone-Sett.description: Gain tools to lead with awareness and the capacity to relate to and work across cultures, and to set structure, feelings, and purpose that support groups and teams. Experiential Leadership Program Certification course. Includes a one-day kayak field activity. No kayaking experience is necessary. Students are billed a materials fee.
STEV 11C - 01 ELP Core Course: Tone-Sett.title: STEV 11C - 01 ELP Core Course: Tone-Setting and Leading with Cultural/Emotional Intelligence

STEV 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.description: Critically interrogates the multiple meanings of "data" and "democracy." Students examine case studies on the mobilization and framing of "democracy" in particular moments. Students also analyze concerns and opportunities provided by "data" management and archival practices of evidence and cataloging.
STEV 175S - 01 Data and Democracy.title: STEV 175S - 01 Data and Democracy

THEA 10 - 01 Introduction to Theater Des.description: Addresses imagination and creativity. Using the framework of theater production, students explore the process of translating a script into a performance. Topics include visual literacy, creative problem solving, establishing effective working teams, tear sheets, storyboarding, drawing, sound and color theory. This course is a prerequisite for all upper-division design courses.
THEA 10 - 01 Introduction to Theater Des.title: THEA 10 - 01 Introduction to Theater Design and Technology

THEA 136 - 01 Choreography II.description: Advanced study, exploration, and analysis of choreographic form and content. Solo, duet, and group work are created with a focus on developing the creative process, interpreting styles and trends, and knowledge of compositional devices and generative movement practices. Enrollment by permission of instructor. May be repeated for credit. (Formerly Choreography.) May be repeated for credit.
THEA 136 - 01 Choreography II.title: THEA 136 - 01 Choreography II

THEA 161P - 01 Theater in the \"Chicano.description: Covers the rise of Teatro Chicano as a cultural-political force within the 1960's "Chicano Power" Movement starting with founding playwriter Luis Valdez and El Teatro Campesino and covering Chicana/o playwrights inspired by the movement, e.g. Cherrie Moraga, Luis Alfaro, and Josefina Lopez.
THEA 161P - 01 Theater in the \"Chicano.title: THEA 161P - 01 Theater in the "Chicano Power" Movement

THEA 20 - 01 Introductory Studies in Act.description: Introduction to basic acting skills and the problems of performance. Concentrates on expanding a range of expression and ability to respond to and analyze dramatic text. Designed for students with little or no experience in acting.
THEA 20 - 01 Introductory Studies in Act.title: THEA 20 - 01 Introductory Studies in Acting

THEA 30 - 01 Introduction to Dance Theor.description: Intensive instruction in developing the dancer's mind/body, with introduction to movement theory and practice. Students are billed a materials fee. May be repeated for credit.
THEA 30 - 01 Introduction to Dance Theor.title: THEA 30 - 01 Introduction to Dance Theory and Technique

THEA 61C - 01 The Birth of the Modern: D.description: Examines dramatic and theatrical works that sprang into being in the wake of the European Renaissance. Follows the ways modern artists have dramatized their questions, struggles, beliefs, and despair in the face of world wars, cultural fragmentation, unprecedented prosperity, and new technologies.
THEA 61C - 01 The Birth of the Modern: D.title: THEA 61C - 01 The Birth of the Modern: Drama and Performance After the Renaissance

THEA 8 - 01 Introduction to Iranian Thea.description: Introduces Iranian theater covering Ta'zieh religious performance, Ruhuzi improvised drama, Naghali storytelling, and modern efforts in national and diasporic theaters fusing indigenous and western styles. No prior knowledge of Iran is required and readings are in English. May be repeated for credit.
THEA 8 - 01 Introduction to Iranian Thea.title: THEA 8 - 01 Introduction to Iranian Theatre

THEA 80A - 01 Introduction to African Am.description: Surveys African American theater from late 19th century to contemporary 21st-century playwrights and examines dramatic narratives to trace creation, evolution, and development of African American cultural identity formation in American theater.
THEA 80A - 01 Introduction to African Am.title: THEA 80A - 01 Introduction to African American Theater

THEA 80N - 01 Walt Disney.description: An examination of Walt Disney's creation of the American vision of "family entertainment." Particular attention will be paid to the classic animated feature films of Walt Disney and to the way this Disney invention has been preserved and developed since his death.  We will also look at the live action films, theme parks, and other Disney creations.
THEA 80N - 01 Walt Disney.title: THEA 80N - 01 Walt Disney

THEA 80R - 01 Bollywood Dance and Cultur.description: Bollywood is the largest film industry in the world. Students learn several fundamental footsteps, eye, hand and body movements, to perform Bollywood dance. They also learn various traditions of Indian classical, folk, and Bollywood dance terms. May be repeated for credit.
THEA 80R - 01 Bollywood Dance and Cultur.title: THEA 80R - 01 Bollywood Dance and Culture in India and Indian Diaspora

WRIT 1A - 01 Introduction to Composition.description: Provides declarative knowledge and procedural knowledge about writing, with a special focus on genre, genre conventions, and rhetorical situation. Provides opportunities for composing in a number of genres. (Formerly Writing 1)
WRIT 1A - 01 Introduction to Composition.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): Writing 27. Enrollment is restricted to first-year students and sophomores.
WRIT 1A - 01 Introduction to Composition.title: WRIT 1A - 01 Introduction to Composition

WRIT 2 - 01 Rhetoric and Inquiry.description: Provides declarative knowledge about writing, with a special focus on writing from research, composing in multiple genres, and transferring knowledge about writing to new contexts.
WRIT 2 - 01 Rhetoric and Inquiry.enrollment_requirements: Prerequisite(s): College 1 and satisfaction of the Entry Level Writing; or College 80A, 80D, or 80F and satisfaction of the C1 requirement. Enrollment is restricted to frosh, sophomore and junior students.
WRIT 2 - 01 Rhetoric and Inquiry.title: WRIT 2 - 01 Rhetoric and Inquiry
